150326775.review:
Si vinieron a este juego esperando un colony sim como yo...ya les digo que es una pérdida de tiempo.
El juego se siente más como un tycoon que un colony sim por la dificultad y loop mal diseñado, y esto es principalmente a la nula necesidad de la distribución. 

¿Se acuerdan de cuando en Rimworld un colono tardaba una hora en llegar a su cama porque la pusiste en la loma del orto? 
Bueno, eso genera una necesidad al tener que darle accesibilidad a colonos únicos, cosa que en este juego es completamente innecesario.
Podés poner la cafetería y el aula en una punta diferente del mapa y no importa porque los alumnos practicamente se teletransportan hasta ella haciendo que no haya necesidad de posicionar estratégicamente NINGUN edificio en la puta escuela, y eso pese a ser SOLO un fallo, ya caga toda la dificultad del juego

Al mismo tiempo este juego NO tiene tutorial y los eventos aleatorios te perjudican el 90% de las veces, y no exagero, son como skillchecks que o tienen probabilidad baja de darte beneficios, O te perjudican completamente, lo cual hace que lo mejor sea ignorarlos ya que lo único que hacen es darte una penalización de "prestigio" que a lo único que te ayuda es a tener más pendejos en la escuela, cosa que no vas a querer.
Sus menús son re toscos, estéticamente es insatisfactorio, no tiene variedad ni razón para decorar la escuela más alla de vos querer gastar plata en decorarla.
Y yo pensé "bueno tiene workshop sooo puedo meterle parches, más items, rediseño del menú, y otras boludeces" PERO la workshop de este juego es una GARCHA que solo te deja descargar otras escuelas y como mucho cambiar alguna textura, NADA MAS

Conclusión: si quieren un tycoon a modo de introducción a juegos más complejos como Rimworld, recomiendo este en caso de conseguirlo MUY barato como yo

no lo vale, compren Rimworld que incluso sin dlcs ni su increíble workshop es más que retante a la vez que disfrutable

137847828.review:
The game is  A W E S O M E.
You can customise the location of the school. Unfortunately you can't change the shape of the logo but you can change what's on there. There's a build phase after you've finished making the uniforms, school name, motto and choosing the principal. The build phase is where you can start building your school including the facilities you'll have there along with researching different topics to become the best. Researching is basically upgrading. You can unlock better teachers, Eco -friendly options with electricity and water, able to unlock more land, maxing out your schools student population to 700, workers work faster, more furniture, walls, floors, plants, fences and gates. The zoning feature is great because you can stop students from interacting with teachers and workers in certain places while the feature also tells you the basic criteria to build the room you want to build. Goons will try and ruin your school, you can easily remove them by completing the detention rooms research. Students are quite unique compared to the staff, they confess their love to other students, they can rebel, they all have different traits, they follow the schedule you make for them alongside having the capability to become ill. The rebelling is that they try skip school, smoke in the bathroom, bully students or are just rude. You can choose what to do as punishments for each type of rebellion. (The only way they are caught is by having monitors at your school.) Overall, you get a great looping experience, every 9 days a new year starts, you compete rival schools while getting ranked for the effort your students put in during their exams. The only downsides to this game is lack of events, school trips, workers bugging out and not doing a single task for either a full hour or whole day, ( I usually just re-spawn the workers.), lack of land to own, too long of days (even on full speed, maybe add another fast forward button?), I also dislike how you can't just view all the students from a certain year. This is because I want to favourite all of my Seniors before they leave so that they feel appreciated and motivated to do more work. Another issue is that the school pet becomes basically useless by the mid to end-game the pets objective becomes obsolete as you have more facilitates to boost your students happiness rates. My final issue with this game is how you can't "start" a game unless you use the normal mode instead of the sandbox that gives you unlimited money but I solved this issue by using a mod. If you enjoy simulator / tycoon / slice of life type games you will enjoy this game's addictive game-play.

132811603.review:
This game is good- It is very similar in style to Prison Architect, but has less intricacy. 

I have enjoyed playing, but once you get the hang of the game-play, it does get repetitive. You pretty much build, fast-forward through the day, get more money and repeat. Even in the hardest game-play mode, it is still easy to manage the school with very little to hold you back. If managed well, you can have the entire skill tree researched in just a couple of school years. 

I really hope the population (student) cap is lifted in future updates, because that is the main drawback in sandbox mode. Some other suggestions would be school wide emergencies that need real management (lock-downs, fires, pandemics, etc.), a Delinquency bar on student info panels (I haven't seen one yet, but let me know if iv'e just missed it), and perhaps a DLC of boarding school/military school with additional management functionality.

Overall I have enjoyed the time put into this game. I have finished all scenarios, and have a successful school on the largest map with 700 happy students. At this time, I have 10 achievements remaining. I will play until they are accomplished, and then probably not play again until there is a DLC/update I am interested in.

RECOMMENDED BUT...
I recommend it, but especially if you are okay with some key issues.

SADLY NO MORE UPDATES
Was abandoned too early IMO, as it could use some updating, QOL updates, expansions and/or dlc. 
Where's the football field? Baseball diamond?

DATED LOOK AND FEEL
Feels and sounds like a game built in the 90's.  (Think Simtower style)
The UI/Menus are large, clunky and can be intrusive at times.
Visually, in some ways this game gives a similiar vibe to Prison Architect (but doesn't have the depth of PA).  

SOUND ODDITY
Ambient sounds are not linked to any student activity but instead are linked to the room/zone you are hovering over.  
(For example, a Music Room/zone will have the sounds of musical instruments playing regardless of whether its occupied or not.)

GAMEPLAY LIMITATIONS
Each regular starting classroom includes 6 subjects: Language, Math, Art, Science, History and PE.  (Aside from some elective classrooms,  this game does not let you create single subject classrooms such as Algerbra 1, Algebra II, Geometry etc. as we have in Amercian High Schools.)  


Although the game mechanics are generally basic, there is still some fun to be had here especially if you can get the game on sale.

127989399.review:
It was fun for awhile; took me maybe 12 hours to burn through the content at a leisurely pace. After that its just repetition and leaving the game running for achievements if that is your thing. 

Pros
-The graphics and soundtrack are pleasant enough.
- The concept of a prison architect style game set in a school is interesting.
- The performance was OK although my prison was quite small and it was still dropping in to the 30s on occasion so I worry about how well it scales.

Cons
- The game feels a little shallow. For example most buildings don't really offer any function or introduce any new mechanics or game-play elements. Maybe they provide some under the hood stat boosts but really other than ticking off grants the building of facilities does not feel very rewarding. 
- There is a system for routing staff members such as setting an explicit path for a Janitor. Unfortunately its cumbersome and actually counter-productive. For example If you have a Janitor on a specific route then they will ignore dirty areas in other parts of the school. Removing the route allows them to be more dynamic and cover more ground.
- Workers occasionally stopped performing tasks for me. I think its maybe if you queue up to many jobs it creates confusion or maybe even kicks out some earlier jobs. This game appears to implement a stack (last in first out) system as opposed to the more traditional queue (first in first out) system. I had to cancel the work and apply it again or sometimes putting additional work tasks in the same general area would be enough.
- The UI is clunky and gets in the way. A lot of the screens were not very intuitive in my opinion and the menus are always taking up a chunk of the screen.

It will be interesting to see where the games goes now since its been acquired by paradox. Will it be the usual story with 50 DLC's (and no season pass) or will the base game get any love as well since its crying out for more content. As it stands now I think it does just enough to get the thumbs up but probably wait for a big sale.

123617473.review:
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Had high hopes because of prison architect, but this game has none of the polish. There's little to no tutorial, which could be fine, but the UI is also incredibly unintuitive and necessary functions are buried behind multiple clicks. Build/object items are listed alphabetically instead of in a more functional and organic order. Some early grants can't be completed until later research is done (without telling you how to do research).

On top of being rather uncomfortable to navigate around in, the UI itself is... just not very pleasant to look at in terms of layout, font choice, and general feel.

It is almost borderline unplayable for someone who has not played a decent amount of prison architect, and it is rather charmless and disappointing for someone who has.

113096230.review:
Academia: School Simulator is poised to become the Prison Architect of education sims -- a welcome arrival to the economic sim genre and a game I have already gotten to sink my teeth into. I am quite proud of myself on this one, as I was wise enough to pick this game up for pennies when it was still on early access. Now that it's worth $20 it is definitely worth the asking price for any fan of the simulation genre, and you should get it now before Paradox turns it into something even better.

This game was a natural buy for Paradox. Although Paradox takes a lot of flack for their DLC scheme, I am a long-time Paradox fan and will throw down the gauntlet to defend their honor if you say there is a better publisher out there. Paradox is very community-centered, offering modding compatibility before it was cool and keeping a keen ear toward fan feedback. Though fans bellyache about their DLC, I have yet to see another company manage to do DLC better, and Paradox would not be able to offer the amazing support they do to their games without the occasional boosts they get from DLC. As a big fan of Cities: Skylines and Prison Architect (as well as their grand strats), Paradox DLC is basically always worth the asking price and it rarely feels as though they're hiding behind a paywall that should've been included in the base game (here's to you, EA.) 

Now that Paradox has picked up Academia: School Simulator, we can expect them to do the same thing they did when they picked up Prison Architect. I had the luck of picking up Academia for pennies when it was in alpha, at a time when it was barely functional. It has come a long way now, as a full-fledged school simulator which has always been a blatant copy of Prison Architect -- and a good copy, no less. Adding its own spin to Prison Architect's successful gameplay structure and turning into an education sim, Academia is already an engrossing success. Now just wait until Paradox gets done with it.

The first thing Paradox did when they acquired Prison Architect was implement many massive free updates. Academia has many small issues that still need to be ironed out, and I expect they'll all be fixed within a few months of the acquisition. We're likely to see free objects, free gameplay additions, bugfixes, scenarios, and more. At its current level, Academia is still a little rough around the edges, though I'm at six hours and counting and I'm still having fun. With the love and experience (and also money) the Paradox team will be able to put into it, I have no doubt that Academia's base game will be massively improved over the next several months and they will do it completely for free.

Then, they'll start adding DLC. This game is ripe for an expansion from grade/primary school into university, and I have no doubt that a university expansion will be among the plans Paradox will lay. The fact that they own Prison Architect will make the addition of dormitories and more complicated schedules easy. A specialized school DLC will also likely happen, adding reform schools and military schools, perhaps even juvenile detention centers... the potential for this game is vast. I have absolutely no doubt Paradox will make this something special.

If you're a fan of the sim genre, you should absolutely pick up this game, even at its $20 price point. It's worth $20 in its current state, but it's also a great investment for the future -- after all, Prison Architect retails for $30.

Fun in stages, but very unfinished and lacking in major QoL features, such as moving items from one place to another,  utility management, staff wage management, adding objects from zones, heatmaps to show congestion or learning effectiveness, turning off zone visibility.

Interesting but unfortunately unfinished and lacking content. Given that this game released more than 4 years ago, I’m really disappointed by the content provided by the game. Incompleteness is everywhere in the game. You will have a question every minutes playing the game:

Why is there no American style school management to choose from, there’s no fun elective classes, all the students has to learn that fixed list of classes. And all the students are divided in to classes.

Why all the students and staff only walk or take school buses to school? I was expecting to build parking lots or bike stands. Why a single school bus could fit like more than 100 students?

How is there swimming pool but no changing room? Students just jumping in to the water with their clothes? 

And don’t say any of the extended school experience: cooking class or school gym, yearbooks, mechanical workshops, holiday events or school prom, musical or band, actual tornado or fire emergencies, school clubs or sports games. These are all not existed. 

This goes on and on and on. At the current point I don’t recommend one from purchasing this game. But since Paradox just acquired this game. Hopefully we will see more updates coming in the future.

107184053.review:
I enjoyed Prison Architect and this game had the same lead artist with the team having a similar game to that in mind, as can be seen by his active presence. Although I've only played Academia: School Simulator on Easy mode so far (ie all the options cash, truancy etc. set generously) it's a much more chilled out experience. No constant struggle with contraband and bloody riots thankfully! Although even on easy budget I failed my first school by not building the classrooms needed to open within the initial budget.

From there though it's not a hard trial and error to get the student's needs satisfied and work toward getting them their best possible grades! The year ticks over quickly and more students (and therefore income) want in your school, soon snowballing to where you can afford to get more ambitious with your setup! Add 'grants' to that and you can get into that position even quicker!

You are dealing with 4 years of students each with names and some variety in appearance, as well as likely having 6 faculty teachers in year 1 also each with names and individual stats. Even the Janitors and Cooks have names! All these make it an addictive pleasure to watch the school schedule tick over in the place you've built, check how the students are doing in their subjects down to individuals if you want, building and tweaking as creatively as you like.

I personally have 3 schools running rather than grinding one into excess and boredom, which is made moe enticing by having 10 uniforms to choose from which can help you feel reason to create a different environment. And if you don't like the provided uniforms; you can download fanmade mods to replace them off steam workshop (easily from within the game) or create your own relatively easily from a template online, along with mods for other areas of the game and game-saves if you want to jump ahead.

Now for the disclaimer that I do tend to find school based games a treat, and there isn't a story mode so the game only really lasts as long as you enjoy getting up to your own devices. Still there's an addictive gameplay loop and plenty of grants and steam achievements you could set your sights on, and a sandbox of imagination to get creative in.

100652461.review:
I find this game very enjoyable. I get a nice warm fuzzy feeling when troubled students get the counseling they need and get into top tier colleges. There is a small bittersweet feeling you get when see these students grow up in your school, have to leave for better things.

Of course, it feels a bit shallow. I achieved the ideal school in less than 24 hours of gameplay, which I suppose isn't the only goal in the game, but that's what mine was, and I feel that was good enough. I think what would push the game over the top would be the addition of more social aspects being implemented. Bullies/crushes are awesome, and these interactions make you root for good outcomes (doesn't always happen of course), but the drama is somewhat interesting. However, there isn't much of it. I wish there were cliques, fads, and trends to contend with. Perhaps, students will resolve to establish territories in non-essential classrooms/area where outsiders are snubbed or bullied. Perhaps, if they walk the walk or talk the talk, they can join the clique. I don't think it has to be only traditional, "Goth, jock, geek" archetypes, but perhaps students who don't fit into these groups create subcultures based on musical/game interest?

I don't know. This is a review, not a suggestion board.
Ryan Sumo, I don't know if you're done with this game, but I loved it, and hope there is more. If not, I think that's cool too.
Thanks.

93393706.review:
I'm just shocked that they haven't been sued for copyright infringement because this is just a slightly reskinned + reprogrammed Prison Architect with kids. It says a lot that I first thought this was made by the same developers and was dumbfounded to find out it wasn't. It was incredibly off putting.

Edit in response to dev: It isn't just the art that Academia shares w/ PA; the programming, the UI, the building and mechanics... If the only thing I can think of when playing a game is how obnoxiously in-your-face similar it is to another, it's a bad game. Sharing style is one thing, but there's far more being shared here than just "art style". If I had to make a comparison, I'd say it stands similar to comparing Sunless Seas to A House of Doors.

It's a wonder this game took 4 years considering how much it """mimics""" PA.
93393706.developer_response:
The game is not "a slightly reskinned + reprogrammed Prison Architect with kids". I was the artist for Prison Architect and while the art of the game bears many similarities with the art I made for PA, there is nothing wrong with that. Other games have mimicked the art style I conceptualized for PA and there is nothing wrong with that either.

With regards to the design, we borrow some elements from PA (and btw PA borrows many elements from other games) that have become standardized in the genre. Other elements like teacher training, student activities, and our randomized events system are things that PA does not have. PA also does not have, AFAIK, people that fall in love and break up with each other.

If you didn't like the game its your right to leave a bad review. But please do not share false statements like this because it is unfair to our team who worked on this game for 4 long years.

91209679.review:
A charming little game reminiscent of Prison Architect, but with a much more lighthearted tone. Fairly basic as far as management sims go, which can make it more accessible to casual gamers (but conversely a little underwhelming for others). Captures the bare bones of simulating a high school, though sometimes overly simple in execution. I do wish the students had a little more simulated in their behavior and interactions, but they are entertaining enough on their own. Definitely way overpriced as it stands; wait for a big sale or give it a test play on a buddy's account before investing in this one. 

Despite it's easy and uncomplicated set up, Academia is straightforward in what it gives you, and for that it's a fun treat. But if you want more bang for your buck, just play RimWorld or Prison Architect. Similar mechanics, but much deeper games.

90694100.review:
Summary: 7/10

I am a long time simulation fan and also one of those weirdos that actually liked school, so this game was up my alley from the start! I didn't get the game until after it was fully released, due to bad experiences with other games, but I've not regretted it. If you enjoy managing games such as Mad Game Tycoon or Prison Architect, this game scratches that same itch. 

The core of the game is completely solid and I hope to see some expanded content to include additional things such as after school activities and/or sports/fine arts competitions to add some diversity to the school year (or I'll just mod it myself <.<).  I've experienced only one bug which was quickly targeted and zapped by the developers in a hotfix. 

My only complaint is that towards the end of the game, it gets kinda stale. You've done most of the grants and most of the check marks to get to the end and aside from three events in the activity hall and random events, there isn't much to focus on except the every day, which can get dull over time.

89022076.review:
Imitation is the sincerest form of flattery but this game takes so much inspiration from Prison Architect that I think there's a legal case to be made. So many things are lifted directly from PA such as staffing (build office zones, hire staffers like lawyers that occupy them one to an office after you research them), research and grants, zones, building methodology (little worker guys hover around Delivery zones then go do it) that it's all jarring in the end. Unfortunately it's all done with an inferior UI that feels like it belongs more in an alpha than a finished product. It lacks polish and detail and seems to achieve the bare minimum while making it hard to see important facts like how your teachers are assigned, or alert you to problems like subjects with no teachers covering them.

What the game really seems to suffer from though is a shallow gameplay loop. You have a build phase at the start of the year and then you kick off the year and then...there's just not a lot to do. Your kids go to class, your janitors clean, your monitors grab the ones smoking in the bathroom, and short of doing some tweaks to logistics there's not a lot of conflict going on here for you to diagnose. Prison Architect solved this by challenging you with things like contraband, intra-prisoner rivalries, riots, and other events, but Academia feels like the team never quite hit on a solid answer to what should keep the player occupied. Some of it feels like roadblocks they threw up to slow down your kids' improvements just to keep you plugging away - for example, a Track improves your kids' P.E. class...but only for Freshmen.

I do feel like the underlying idea here is great. It just needed a more solid UI and core gameplay loop and to break free of the Prison Architect source material that it was obviously, incredibly inspired by.

86025024.review:
I picked up Academia at the start of the early access program -- and held onto it all through it's development and up through release. 

Sadly, now that the game has hit a "released" 1.0 version from the developers, I simply cannot recommend this game at full-price.  Academia itself is a great concept for a less-gritty Prison Architect where you run, build, and manage a school.  You have to deal with staff, grades, problem-students, budgets, schedules, the list goes on...

Unfortunately, the game comes across as trying to be a mile-wide but only an inch-deep.  There's lots of basic things missing from the game you would expect to be commonplace, like relocating objects.  There's also a it-just-gets-the-job-done UI which -- at times -- has little to no data for you to work off of.  For instance, when planning meals for your cafeteria(s), there is zero feedback given to the player of if you are making enough food, have enough serving lines, cooks, food stocks, or etc.  You just have to spam-place objects down until you stop having students drop-out or complain about being hungry for lack of any analytical data to go off of. 

The research tree can be fun to unlock more stuff for your school, but the first "school year" can be very hard; requiring you to only build the bare-minimum room sizes and objects or risk running out of money to continue. While this is just a preference thing and you can change your starting funds on a new game, it makes each play-though feel remarkably identical.

There are game over scenarios here -- if you have over 50% of your students either being delinquent or sick, you get shut down.  This isn't that big of a deal, except for the random events that happen throughout your gameplay.  You can ignore these events and lose reputation instead, but doing so is a rough shot-in-the-foot to any progress.  The events aren't always that bad and sure you could save-scum to get around them, but in my last two play attempts in 1.0, I got an earthquake event that required me to either lose $8,000 in-game which I didn't have at the time, or have something like 40+ objects break and over half the student body instantly get injured.  This results in a game over at the end of the day because there's no way you can get your students back healthy before the end of the day without an infirmary level nursing station, which you won't have or afford in the first day(s) of your school. 

So, the TLDR here:

Game at the surface is fun if you can get past a basic UI, lack of a few come-to-expect gameplay functions for this genre of game, sometimes punishing random events, and the need to watch the game in fast-forward to get more money to really do anything.  The game is fun, so if you can grab it on sale I would say it's worth getting, but it still needs some more additions before I would personally say it's ready for a full-release and the full-price; especially when you can get games like Prison Architect frequently on sale at this price or less which currently has a more fleshed out and (dare I say) "finished" feel. 

I have nothing but respect for this dev who has always been willing to communicate, and I hope the game keeps getting worked on into the future, because if some glaring missing functions and data-reporting was there which isn't, it would be worth $25-30 easy because the concept is fun.  Right now it sadly comes across as ~80% complete and not ready... yet.

[h1]If building prison is starting to boring you, try building school instead[/h1]

Ok. first of all, I have to declare that my review will be very comparing to that one game you might know, Prison Architect (PA). Why? because it feel like PA a lot, it even look like one with those 2D graphic. Heck, I even thought it come from the same developer or even a clone at first.

So, as you can guess, I play PA a lot back then, and I have a lot of fun time with it, so when I saw Academia, I didn't expect much. But how wrong I am, It is very fun and addictive, and I even think that I have enjoy this game more than PA.

Why I enjoy this game?
First of all, it have all depth almost similar to PA, research tree, personal stat, a lot of movement and interaction between things and characters. They remove the foundation system that PA have and restriction on minimum size of room which is very nice for me, so in order to build a building you just need to build wall around and that all.
There is no pipe and electrical wire system, which I also don't miss it much.
The downsize is that, it seem to have a limited number of student that you can have, and limited plot of land that you can expand. And you need to manual click broken thing in order to repair which I hope it can be done automatically.

Doesn't seem quite ready for release.

There's too little feedback of why stuff happens or doesn't happen and, more importantly, some features just seem broken and others that feel like should exist don't.

Scheduling doesn't work - your students will ignore it and go to lunch at 12 PM, no matter if they were supposed to have a class at that time. If you set lunch at any other time, they will just hang around - and then go to lunch at 12 PM.
[b]Edit:[/b] This was a bug, it has been corrected.

Students will randomly drop out due to "not being able to eat", despite it being able 9 AM, just one hour into school. There's no feedback to explain why.

You can build stuff for your staff, like lounge rooms, comfortable objects, etc - but does it matter? Staff doesn't display any measure of needs or wants, so it seems like such a feature was never implemented, despite it feeling like it should be.

Do crowded corridors affect students? Does it matter if different classes get to share recess together or not? There's no feedback on any of that, but it seems that it doesn't.

All in all, I like the theme of this game a lot more than Prison Architect, but unfortunately the game itself isn't there.

81920000.review:
While this is typically my type of game having 58 hours on another brick in the mall and 90 on prison architect, I had great hopes coming into this game. However I quickly found out that this game was lacking content as once you got the basic set up and then build the rooms such as for the pool or clinic I found myself at the point where all that was left for me to do was decorate, build more classrooms and buy the limited land you can buy. Which was after a mere 3 years in game or about 3-5 hours of game play for me. Now I would typically not do reviews for games I have such little hours on as this but seeing that the game got announced that it is going out of early access.

What I would like to see added/improved
-Sports teams, my school high school had 500 kids and we still managed to have a bunch of sports teams, plus you already have the fields for them and this would work great prestige systems for schools
-Unique classes, once again small school but it still offered a third language class, a wood shop class, a mechanics class
-Unlimited land expansion
-Better optimization of building especially while placing down large amounts of lets say grass as when I place down a large area I get a stutter for a second and I have a previous gen cpu (ryzen 3600 @4.1GHz) which should be more than enough
-Better builders construction/priority system The builders rn seem to build what you placed down first so when you make major infrastructure plans on opposite sides of your map your workers will run from one side to the other
-Perhaps multifloor schools even if limited to 2 floors this would be great if the unlimited land expansion isnt possible

All that said I will certainly keep an eye on this game and see what gets added with time, but unless a fair bit more content is gonna get added before the release next year this will probably be where this game ends for me.

77519652.review:
I really wish I could recommend this game because it's not bad, but in it's current form it doesn't have enough gameplay.

It is too easy. Ultimately, that is what my review boils down to. After 2 or 3 years you find yourself just waiting for time to pass. I would say around 1/3 of the time I've played has been spent on waiting for the academic year to end so I can actually do something. The scenarios make this game for me but they are also too easy and can be completed quickly. There is very little management needed and it just becomes a game of "lets make a pretty school". That being said, school design is certainly a strength of this game.

Even with the custom difficulties there aren't enough delinquents or sick students for it to pose a challenge. All the hardest difficulty settings do is determine how long you'll be sat waiting with nothing to do because you have no money, and won't be getting any money until you can attract enough students. The only challenge to it is how tediously slow time passes when you have nothing to do in-game.

Going forward, for me to recommend the game, I want to see significantly harder scenarios or things like custom scenarios/enrolment settings where we can choose the % of delinquents/sick students we want per year for example. Disasters (e.g. fires, earthquakes, epidemics) would also be a nice addition to increase difficulty and, combined with custom settings, we could set the frequency/severity and/or a grace period if we wanted to so we can get our school up and running first; this would add more gameplay to long term saves when things get boring. Adding staff age/retirement would mean we have to really consider who to hire, whether they're worth the money, and when we'll need to hire new staff to replace them once they leave. Student satisfaction/needs could include career pathways e.g. a student wants to be a scientist but you have no science lab so that lowers their satisfaction. There's a lot they could add but, if nothing else, the time needs to pass faster.

Again, it is in no way a BAD game, it just needs more to it and I'm hopeful that they'll continue updating it.

75935511.review:
Academia School Simulator is off to a good start. I've found it quite fun and put in many hours but I do agree there is quite a bit lacking in the game. There's also a lot of infuriating game mechanics that almost ruin the game for me and are making it hard to want to continue playing the game in its current state. 

Starting off with the positives. I like the customisation you get for your school and how you can decorate. It is very similar to Prison Architect as mentioned. The game has run very well for me and the graphics are cute. 

Now on to the negatives. Oh boy. 
Sometimes I feel like I'm playing School Janitor Simulator instead as the hygiene mechanic in the game is beyond broken. This is my biggest grief with the game. Dirt gets everywhere even when I set the level to 'Tidy' and your janitors have a hard time keeping up with the amount of dirt being produced. The students then complain the school is too filthy and drop out which lowers your income. You hire more janitors which also lowers your income but the school is still too filthy. This creates an endless loop of students dropping and you losing more and more money. This makes playing scenarios immensely frustrating because it makes it way more difficult than it needs to be and you're way too likely to fail due to just not having enough funds and not being able to bring it back. Unpaved dirt also tanking your overall cleanliness school is really stupid also. It's...the ground...why are we counting the grass and ground as dirty?! The janitors also act poorly in their AI. They clump together on the routes instead of spreading out and with janitor priority they ALL go instead of just the ones without a route as stated in the tooltip. Basically, you end up researching Janitor Priority as fast as possible then spending all your time telling the Janitors where to clean. Not what I signed up for.

Next is the grading system. Not sure if it's just buggy but I definitely find it ridiculous. With level 1 teachers, even if at the end of the school year your students grade levels are all in the green they will still overwhelmingly fail. It forces you to get level 2 teachers which tank your income fast. Heck, even with level 2 teachers you still get a weirdly high number of students who fail. But if you don't get a good grade you don't get enough students interested so you don't get much tuition money. This again starts a nose dive to failure. It's not that I don't want a challenge, it's that it's too difficult to come back from having a drop like that and it just ends up in failing or starting the save over. The other hand is that it gets way too easy. 

Next the random events are a nuisance and don't have much variety. It's pretty much 'spend money you don't have or 90% chance to lose stuff'. Pay $3000 for only 10 prestige? No way. I find myself just skipping them and taking the -5 prestige penalty instead because it's simply not worth it. You may get the good event where you can just get some money ($1000) or prestige (100) but I don't get those much. They're also very repetitive. 

Then you realise that there isn't really all that much to the game. You really don't need to build more than just basic classrooms if you don't want to unless you want the grant money or the scenario tells you to. You get better teachers, build the school bigger and that's it. The various sporting rooms are per class group which I don't think should be a thing (why only seniors for basketball or only juniors for swimming?). The game is in early access and I do think it has a good amount of beautification options right now so I'm not bothered on getting more for now but there does need to be a lot more gameplay elements to it. How about the option to put on our own events? Plan the graduation ceremony? (As of right now students just disappear in to the cosmos when they graduate). More random events that do something other than spending money to still lose some staff or students. What if the school inspector was more than just a random event pop up? Plenty of ideas.

Overall, my conclusion is they have a good beginning here and I have enjoyed the time I have played but I would recommend anyone who is looking to purchase to wait until they put more into this game and fix the glaring issues because you'll get bored very quickly. I'm mainly treating this game as an idle game at this point. I look forward to what the developers do in the future and hope it can make me return but for now I cannot recommend it.
75935511.developer_response: Thanks for the great feedback! We're currently making changes to some of the issues you've raised, including janitor balancing, more varied events, and other balancing issues.

Nos encontramos con un juego de "gestión" muy entretenido y jugable.

Really enjoy the game but there needs to be more. By year 4 in game, I completed most of the research and built mostly everything and the money was raking in. I think there needs to be more competition elements to engage in, not just the overall ranking. My suggestions:

-Add in extra-curriculum clubs during dismissal. I know some students already hang around in various rooms but it would be good to have proper clubs.
-Have these clubs compete with other schools. E.g. sports leagues, debate competitions, spelling bees - not just random events!
-Micromanage the class schedule. I'd love to make like "an art school" or a "science school" with more lessons dedicated to certain subjects.
-More reasons to "zoom in" and watch the students. I think there should be cliques, e.g. bullies, jocks, nerds, etc. 

Other than a few extra things to make the game more fun, I think this is a brilliant game and I do enjoy it and would 100% recommend it if you like building games.

68528181.review:
Original Review: 5/3/2020

I have had my eyes on this game for a long time, but sadly it just doesn't cut it. Seems to be very poorly balanced in the beginning, or something, I really don't know...
I enrolled 40 students at the beginning of my first year, and I had less then 20 by day 9. The students kept dropping out because it was "too boring", but I had a common room, and I couldn't do anything because I was in negative cash flow for 90% of my play time. I don't know if it's a balance issue or a bug with the latest update, but my god was it annoying. I tried multiple tries to research other things first etc, but the students kept leaving and you slowly lose more and more money, until I couldn't do anything anymore. By day 9 my teachers were costing more than my students were able to pay me for tuition. Grants helped temporarily, but I could never get back into positive cash flow. Refunded for now, maybe I will check on the game in a few months or so.

Edit 5/5/2020
I purchased the game again, its quarantine time, what else can I do? Hopefully the problem has been fixed, would love to see how a new school goes!
Played the game for almost 4 hours straight and only had one or two dropouts, wonderful! Thank you for fixing the issue so fast, and I'm very glad I gave the game another opportunity

68493687.review:
I regret buying this. Superficially it's a business management sim game in the same vain as Prison Architect, Another Brick in the Mall or older games like Theme Hospital. But the reality is it's half baked - there isn't much depth to the mechanics or play. I've played two schools in 3 hours, in both I was able to research the full student portion of the research tree and built everything, and discover it made little impact - I keep losing students because my school is "boring". 

The rest of the research tree and mechanics are largely about scaling up the logistics to support a larger school. But that seems to be it. This lacks all the subtly and challenge of the the other games. Theme Hospital for example had scenarios and scaled up the challenge over the course of the game. This is just everything on a plate and you realise it's not much of a meal. From what I can tell not much has changed over a few years in early access.

I contrast this with Another Brick in the Mall which has constantly upgraded the mechanics and game play until it reached 1.0. This game just doesn't compare unfortunately. Sorry but at the moment I can't recommend this game.
68493687.developer_response: Hi! Thanks for trying out the game and giving feedback. We are trying to investigate whether the students finding the school 'boring' is a bug or a balancing issue. As for mechanics and depth,would like to hear more about what you think would improve the game more in terms of depth.

I bought this game when it first arrived on the scene, even then it had a lot to offer in means of a overhead simulation gaming. The game is updated regularly and is taken seriously for the fans. It's still in early access and I see the enthusiasm by the creators. You are to design a school of any kind from your imagination (personally I attempt to go for a Japanese based school), from naming your school, creating a motto, your colors, how you see your school being, the type of clothing to be worn, type of principle you desire, pretty much anything you can think of you can have in this game. Depending on your style, you can either make a nice profit or you can get carried away and go bankrupt. I love the balance between both and the fact there is a sandbox mode. 

The only thing I would say is needed, at least for a Japanese school builder style like myself, is to have multiple floors being an addition. With that being said, this game is well worth every penny you spend on it and it keeps me entertained.

64856377.review:
The itself has a really nice concept. I thoroughly enjoyed it, until I came to the endgame. I've completely played it through, although I didn't have the patience to wait for the last couple of achievements. 

My pro's and cons are:

+ New type of environment as I never played a decent school-based game.
+ Easy to learn interface
+ Nice stats
+ Fun to see your school improve.

- Too little content so far, after 15 hours I'm completely finished.
- It's basically Prison Tycoon in a new environment.
- When you research power and can sell back to the government, you basically never have to worry about cash again.

To sum it up:

A nice little game, which is easy to play and brings about 10 hours of fun to the people that like the genre. 

Current grade: 7/10

Possible grade when more content is added: 8.5/10

63185600.review:
This game was a lot of fun for me. For a few days I was pretty much addicted to it. There was a lot to amuse me; the initial chaos of having to scrape the school together with little time and stuff going wrong, the achievement of getting that under control enough to start focusing on my long-term plan for what I wanted the school to look like, the thrill of transforming the landscape bit by bit to fit that long-term plan, and the unfettered joy of watching the school function like a perfectly made swiss watch once my plan was implemented.

I would highly recommend this game. 

That said, however, I would NOT recommend this game at its full list price of $20, because after that addiction period I was essentially done. There's little to no replay value, and there's not a lot of variation in the directions that one can take with their school. There's a LOT of potential if the devs opened it up with a much better modding system and allowed us to tinker with the many many MANY feature implementation requests that exist on the community page, but they pretty much seem to have moved on to their next game and left this largely by the wayside.

My advice to you is to put this game on your wishlist and nab it immediately when it's on a 50% or greater sale.

60951941.review:
[h1] Academia : School Simulator Review [/h1]
[u] December 30th, 2019 [/u]

[b] Price [/b]
Sale Price: $14.99
Normal Price: $19.99
I purchased this game on sale with the on-going winter sale. I had some money to spare and I grabbed it. I think both prices are decent considering it is a simulator game with pixel graphics ( which are both completely fine but ultimately are easier to make than full 3D games etc. ) That being said, I was pleasantly surprised with the amount of time I've spent playing this game and not getting bored. I've sunk about 12 hours over the past 3 days (I forgot to shut my PC off at night with the game on increasing the hours it says I've played. I think if you have some extra money lying around or it goes on sale its a worth while buy.

[b] Gameplay [/b]
The game itself is fun and addicting. The principle task as per most simulation/management games is taking whatever the simulator is (school, prison etc) and growing and upgrading attempting to reach max efficiency and productivity. In this case, you're the principle of a school and you're tasked with growing and expanding the school. This is done through building, researching upgrades, hiring teachers, completing grants and so on. In doing so you will be rewarded with cash rewards and a reputation system called "Prestige". Your schools prestige determines how it will be ranked among 999 other schools, higher the prestige- better the rank. At the end of the school year which takes place over 9 days, your schools rank will be determined for that year along with your exam results and cash rewards. The goal is to reach rank one while continuously growing and expanding and dealing with the issues that come along with that. I think this is a great simulator game and has a steady base to grow from with continued updates. 

[b] Pros [/b]
- Easy to sink many hours into
- I've only personally crashed once in my 12 hours of play as a result of placing a racing track (not sure why lol)
- Not over-complex, the game adds new features gradually allowing you to fully understand the previous before moving onto the next
- UI is simple and easy to look at and understand

[b] Cons [/b]
- Slow paced, the 9-day school year is may seem short but each day feels very long even at 3x speed which isn't that fast. 
- Due to the long days, money is difficult to come by. Most revenue comes from day to day tuition fees which alone are very underwhelming. 
- There's a lack of content. This is less of an issue as the developer seems to be updating it with new stuff but it's in need of some new core systems to add to the game as it can become very stale. Both the grant system and researching upgrades can be completed fairly quickly which feels like a dead end as the only other goal you have is becoming number 1.
- The 'Sell to the Grid" perk is busted. On my main campaign save file, 1/8 of my map is wind turbines essentially giving me infinite money allowing me to bypass any financial difficulty. It takes away from being a school simulator and turns into a power plant simulator.

How to abuse "Sell to the Grid' [ I AM SAYING IT SO IT CAN BE FIXED, DOING THIS WILL RUIN THE GAME ]
[spoiler] After researching up to the "Sell to the Grid" perk, every morning when you receive the schools daily income, spend most of it on wind turbines. I prefer to section them off to the side so it does not interfere with building. Each wind turbine gives you $500 to daily revenue. So each day you buy a few which allow you to buy more the next day, so on and so forth. This makes your revenue double every couple of days. I have about 700 turbines giving me 350k a day. [/spoiler]

-At the beginning of each day, a sum of money is taken from your account to pay for expenses? (It's not specified) The amount needed per day is no where to be found meaning if you don't have a large sum of money left over at the end of day, the school may close down due to lack of funds. You can reload the save as the game auto-saves every morning and you'll have zero dollars in your funds and the day will go on as normal.

-The kids are never happy. Each kid has needs: access to food, bathrooms, rest (places to sit), fun (recreational rooms) and safety. No matter how many toilets you install in the school or how big the cafeteria is, there will always be complaints about having to use the bushes as bathrooms or there not being enough food. Out of spite I have placed 500 toilets in my main save with only 450 students and yet still some students have the nerve to use the bush. Janitors seem to be very slow or do not do their job at all. With only 450 kids I have 108 janitors but the school is apparently "filthy" to the students. This though was referenced in the discussion post on future plans for the game. 

TLDR: The game is really fun but needs some fixing and improvements
7/10 (in its current state)

56984199.review: I recommend the game, because it will scratch that building/management itch for a while.  It's a pretty basic game, build a school, hire teachers, fill the needs of the students.  Too me though, it's so basic, after a good few days of playing, you've done everything, and it just becomes sitting there watching the same thing over and over.  To me, the game lacks anything that would be "fun" or could make some real thinking.  There are no sports in this school game, no football team, which is pretty much the backbone of high schools today.  There are no competitions of any sorts, no chess team, no glee club, no debate team, no track team, nothing.  You just have students that come, teachers that teach, and then random stuff might happen, like a student leaves because he can’t find a toilet or there isn’t enough food.  Teachers don’t get better or worse, your schools don’t compete at all.  After you have your school running, there really isn’t anything to do.  There isn’t even a graduation in the game, no ceremony, just at the end of the year, you get a grade card, you can see how each student did, and that’s it.  The price is a decent price and there is enough enjoyment for around 10-15 hours, but it is very basic without a whole lot of depth.

It's an okay game, certainly worth the small price, but it feels a little shallow. Money is basically infinite, and everything is automated out of the gate, so there's really no reason to not throw more bodies at the problem. Dirty? Hire 30 janitors and plant 30 wind turbines. Need better grades? Research the skill that lets you get perfect teachers every time. 

Maybe I just didn't get far enough. I only got to 300 students, but with a copy/paste I think it could have been 1k with very minimal effort. 

I'm not sure what's different between this and Oxygen Not Included, but that captivated me for literally 100x as long. Perhaps it's the scarcity and risk of failure; I don't feel like I _can_ fail at this game. Even on hard mode. 

At least it's moving away from the prison theme though. That's progress! Thank you for that!

55736514.review:
Potential to be an addictive micromanager/builder in the vein of Prison Architect, but it needs a lot of polish, mainly in the area of balancing.

As it is, costs and financing create an extremely narrow path to survival- it's very difficult to build even a basic functioning school without following the sequence of grants in JUST the right way to simply get things on the ground without going bankrupt- there's not much room to be creative or interesting until you're very profitable, which take quite a while.

Nearly every construction is locked behind a long research tree that's very time-consuming and expensive- and, again, needs to be done in JUST the right order to unlock the essential functions without going broke.

There's very little in the way of guidance- the tutorial is extremely brief and doesn't explain how the game components work beyond the very first steps. It's very easy to spend yourself into a corner before you've even opened the school.

Also, there's ONE song played on an endless loop. After a while, you forget what sanity felt like.

Academia : School Simulator is one of those "Tycoon" style games that is just simply fun to play. The familiarity of the build process (Think Prison Architect) is comforting. But, hold on.... It's actually a bit better! The Research Tree is easy to follow and the Grant System works well for a natural progression to the game. The UI is easy to follow and figure out as well.

Now on to the important stuff... The graphics are adorable. It looks really nice and the art style is fun, like you would hope it would be. The little stories that take place between students adds a little life and flavor to the entire process. These aren't just Sim Students marching through your Scheduled Routine. They have interests and needs and feelings. They fall in Love, they crush on other students without reciprocation... Who can't relate to that? They want food, they want music, they want what we all wanted while in school.

Overall, in this stage of development, it is really well fleshed out. With regular updates that keep the game growing and fresh. 

Take a chance, you'll enjoy it!

I'm a big fan of the detail that went into making the students and staff feel less like automatons and more human-like: All kinds of need bars, love confessions, teachers have names and degrees, students take equipment for classes out of cabinets and bring them back, students check out lockers between classes, bullying incidents, and so forth. I hope that's a part that will be expanded even more in various ways (for example with more student traits, the only ones right now are negative traits that you have to fix through counseling) since seeing the students "do stuff" in the environment the player created is the most fun part for me.

55148507.review:
[b] Overview [/b]
If you’ve ever wanted to design a school from the ground up, you’ve come to the right place. Academia: School Simulator gets you in at the conception phase as you lead your institution from establishing its name and emblem to achieving Ivy League greatness. Every step along the way involves you and the decisions that you make including not only the construction and design of its structures but also in who is employed there and the environment and overall routine of those who populate your center of learning.

[b] The Founding Of Your Very Own School [/b]
When you first start your game you are brought to the school customization screen. Here you decide on your school’s name, motto, emblem, and student uniform as well as the difficulty settings for your game. There are a number of options to mess around with to your liking and you are certainly not lacking in freedom of choice, though I would have liked even more options; the addition of teacher uniforms and biomes, for example, could do wonders for further differentiating one school from the next. However, even in its current state, the customization on this screen is more advanced and in-depth than one might assume and it was an enjoyable and intuitive experience that created a first impression that made me quite optimistic about the game that I was about to buckle down and play for several hours.

[b] The Ribbon Cutting Ceremony [/b]
No, you’re not actually getting a ribbon-cutting ceremony. Once your school is founded you will find yourself looking at a large, empty plot of land graced only with a road and a significant number of trees and bushes. This is where you will spend the vast majority of the game, the exception only being at the end of each year with a brief summary of your institution’s performance. Your first step will be the construction of a principal’s office and starting with this the keys to the castle are in your hands and within moments, you’ll be introduced to three of the most integral aspects of Academia: School Simulator: grants, admissions, and staffing.

Grants are tasks that you can complete for additional funding that payout both in advance and upon completion. This type of funding is very important to the future success of your school and the tasks may include anything from hiring a few janitors and placing a few trash cans to researching and constructing a library.

Admissions are key to the success of your institution as they are the primary source of your income. Each year, including the first, you are informed of the number of students that have applied to attend your school and you may choose to accept as many of them as you have the capacity for. Every student comes with an upfront tuition cost that is immediately added to your treasury upon the start of the school year as well as having the effect of increasing the subsidy that you receive daily as long as they continue to remain in attendance.

Your staff is just as important as your student body as your school will simply not function without them. Most of the staff in the game are generic currently, for example, one cook is exactly the same as the next cook regarding their wages and efficiency although they may have varying names and appearances. Your teachers are the one exception to this rule and they are a major one; every teacher has a set of six skills, one for each subject that is taught at your school, and this determined how capable they are of ensuring that your students achieve the highest grades that they can. The better your students perform, the more your school is rewarded, the more its prestige grows, and the larger the number of candidates who seek to join your ranks the following year will grow. Teachers are separated into three categories as well: Bachelor’s, Master’s, and Doctorate degrees that offer significantly different levels of efficiency in their teaching as you might imagine.

[b] But How Are The Graphics? [/b]
The graphics and audio are not by any means going to push any system to its limits unless you are breaking out your Commodore 64 for the experience. I enjoy the simple art style and it never caused me to feel as if my immersion had been broken, as a matter of fact, the simplicity played in its favor by always keeping me on track and avoiding any distractions that came up. The music and sound effects were above average as well and worked well for the game, there weren’t many but they set the mood as calm and relaxed, similar to something that you might hear in a game like Stardew Valley. In short, both the graphics and the audio work well for the game but they most likely won’t be blowing anyone’s mind.

[b] What Is Solid? [/b]
I played through nearly all of the content in this game twice on the default settings before writing this review and there are a number of features that are enjoyable. The first time, I made a ‘classic’ school that was a single building and designed to be a standard prep school and chose to use the British school uniforms (Gianni Bato Prep); the second time, I decided to make a military academy campus that was split into several buildings and the students were required to wear military dress (Marshmallow Military Academy). I was happy to see that both were efficient and that neither seemed to be a worse option than the other. I also enjoyed the variety of room types that you can unlock for your school, everything ranging from libraries to AV rooms to a variety of sports-focused rooms and so on; I never felt that my options were limited in this regard. The reports that are available to you were some of the most streamlined and efficient ones that I have seen in a game of this type, I always knew exactly what needed to be improved to keep my students fulfilled and out of trouble.

During the time that I played I encountered only one real issue with the game and it was one that was text-based. One of the grants on the list had a requirement that was not accurate for the technology required to unlock the building that was the only other requirement to receive the completion funds. I notified the developers via Steam and received a response within only a few hours of sending it that included a genuine ‘thank you’ and it added another layer of optimism for me that this game is destined to be great in the future.

[b] What Can Be Improved? [/b]
As contradictory as it sounds after reading my earlier praise, I believe that additional rooms would certainly add to the longevity of the game. Although my first school took several hours to get to the point of unlocking all of the content for building, on my second run I had it all constructed on my campus within an hour and a half.

I would also suggest additional challenges that arise during the course of your institution’s career. My first year with Gianni Bato Prep was fairly challenging but by the time the windfall of funds from admissions arrived at the beginning of the second year, I never had any financial difficulty again. I still very much enjoyed the casual nature of building and managing a growing school but there was nothing left that offered a challenge. My experience with Marshmallow Military Academy was simply casual from start to finish after having learned the nature of the game previously.

[b] Verdict [/b]
My overall recommendation on this game currently is to pick it up if you’re a fan of management and construction games like Prison Architect, these games are very similar in their feel even if their themes are quite different. The game that is currently available to be played is certainly playable, I didn’t feel that I was grinding through the hours to experience enough to write this review, I genuinely enjoyed every second in the game. It could certainly use more content, though, and within less than a dozen hours, I had experienced nearly everything that the game had to offer.

54887212.review:
This game is fun enough that I've invested 14 hours so far into it, which is a lot considering I don't usually have the attention span for games I'm not enjoying. Depending on your budget, that amount of fun may justify the price all by itself. The game is very similar to prison architect, but because it is still in development it is without the wealth of features that those games have.

Pros:

- The game looks well polished, with intuitive interfaces, good graphics (for the genre of management game it is) and nice ambient sounds + music.

-The gameplay is just as fun as Prison Architect and the game sets you progression goals to keep you engaged.

-There is a nice element of world-building as you seek to outperform other schools, but this is more of a side feature than a fully fleshed out concept.

-You can enjoy this game casually or invest a lot of time into routing your employees and making your school incredibly efficient.

Cons:

-The game is missing some key features that will make your experience more frustrating and uninteractive. The major issue is that you cannot route or assign your cooks, and given that you will most likely build multiple cafeterias for your staff and students, your cooks will try to evenly distribute regardless of the size of each cafeteria, leaving you either understaffed or forced to employ a surplus of cooks in order to make sure food gets made for your students.

-Late game scaling will scare off casual players, because as you expand into your map you will begin to require great degrees of area micromanagement. Your students get 1 hour lunch breaks to eat and relax, but if you don't place recreational facilities and cafeterias at multiple locations, they very often can't make it to one of these rooms in time. Some might say that this isn't an issue, but rather a feature of the genre, but it often means that you will spend a large portion of the beginning of the game mapping out the structure of your whole school many years in advance, preventing you from actually jumping in and just playing the game.

In summary, a good game, worth investing in, but you will probably get bored of it after a while until new features are implemented and game fixes are made. Given the fact that this game is moddable and still in early development, it's safe to say that these things will eventually be fixed and/or improved.

I loved this school tycoon game! I had so much fun with hunting down the achievements. It has a lot of grindy one and after a while that was boring, but I still enjoy this game so much.  Before you start a game you have the option to choose how your students behave, are they angels or devils, or maybe something in between. Are they tidy, or messy, stuff like that. This will help you with hunting down specific achievements. You choose also which outfit they will wear, and on the steam workshop there are a lot more options, even harry potter uniforms! 

After you choose all the basic stuff and gave your school a name and slogan you'll start your new school with a big piece of land on which you'll start building your school. Once you have built the basics you can accept students and start the school year. During the school year, you can keep on building, but you can't accept new students during the school year, only at the start of a new one.  This game has a lot of different kind of rooms you can resource and add to your school. The game will give you "to-do quests" which help you get through the game easily. 

As stated above this game has achievements that are grindy, very very grindy. You can save at any moment during the game and you can reload a save file while keeping the stats you already had. This will make some achievements so much easier.  Like the achievements for students with bad behavior. There are "quests" that will give you 10 student of each of the 3 bad behavior types. I made a new save file just before accepting those and kept reloading day 1 that they arrived because it felt that they behaved the most horrible during that first day. This trick also comes in handy with the achievement for earning 100k dollar through vending machines. This might be the most grindy achievement in the game.

Oh, How the times have changed. After the original review (from 5 hours of play) I am now at 20 hours. I have got to say that the game has drastically improved and I would recommend anyone who played the game in the past to give it another go. It is in immediately fun game (I played on Hard) as the mix of challenge and objectives are great. I found myself having to start 3 separate schools in-order for me to get to (effectively) the end of the game where I had completed most grants and my cash-flow was positive. The game has become FUN to an extent which is great! 

My only few problems (And I know it is an Early Access, these are mainly Ideas) is that some feature do not seem to work properly. The food situation is very difficult to handle and hard to manage. Some UI feature to work out production vs demand would be great (Similar to the prison architect style). I also don't understand why the Bus would be used, you are charged money and seemingly get nothing in return. If there is a reason for this a better explanation would be needed (IMO).

In conclusion the game has vastly improved and I would now recommend it to someone who likes games such as Prison Architect and Rimworld.

54494519.review:
TL;DR
It's fine, but not worth $20 because it has very little replay value.

Overview
Academia: School Simulator is a game. It's challenging to call it a good game, but it certainly isn't a bad one. I originally purchased this game after seeing it on youtube and being interesting in a school sandbox game, in which I could do a variety of things from build the best school, to making a living hellscape. Academia: School Simulator, did not meet those expectations.

Story
I don't truly demand story in every game I play, but I feel like this could use a little... anything? I dunno even just a: Gramps left me his inheritance and I was told to spend it on his dying wish: building a school. Whatever, moving on.
0.0/2.0

Gameplay
I can't really bang to much on the game, other than being repetitive. There are plenty of somewhat interesting options, like research pathways, school blueprints, and transfer students. Solid gameplay with reasonable controls and strategy. Acceptable.
1.3/2.0

Art
Graphics
Graphics are good. Original enough character design and good looking sprites. Most objects are solids colors, but have enough detail to make it feel realistic. Not a masterpiece, but pleasant to look at.
Sound
Music was not memorable, but I remember it was there. There were probably sound effects too. That I don't remember say a lot about how good the sound was. Mediocre.
1.2/2.0

Enjoyment
Alright, here's where I have an issue:
Initially, the game is fun enough to try to build the greatest school and become the top school in the world. After taking a few in-game years to build your school, you just need to slowly accommodate more students and get better teachers to climb the ranks. Now sit and wait while the game slowly runs through a dozen or so years to become the top school. While it doesn't really stay interesting the whole time, the concept seems fine enough, yes? Here's where it gets ya: there really is no replay value. Sure, you can build a new school, in a different orientation, but it you want to make progress you have to use all the same rooms and fit all the same parameters. It's like if every time you have a sandwich, you have the choice the assemble it a different way, but you only have 4 different ingredients: ham, cheese, mustard, and bread. There are only so many ways to put it together, and even when it's a different order of ingredients it still tastes the same. Very much like this game. Another thing I wanted to do with the game was experiment with my limits (e.g. taking away food, locking students in, etc.). Very much to my dissapointment, in game students whose need aren't met just up and leave and don't come back. How fun. Locking students in means that only half will appear the next day and the rest will reappear outside the building. And finally, probably just a problem on my end, trying to make class sizes huge. Adding hundreds of desks to a single classroom. Doesn't work. Crashed my game. More than once. Honestly all in all unhappy with this game's failure to have replay value. I tend to spend my money on games I know I will seriously enjoy, games I know I will come back to and play again. I was expecting that with this game. Did not deliver.
0.3/2.0

Bonus points
+0.3 Wide selection of random selected names and character designs.
+0.2 Relatively accurate depiction or school management
Yup. this sure is an okay game.
0.5/2.0

Conclusion
I understand this game is still not complete, so some of the issues that I had may still be fixed. They may have been fixed before I even post this. Regardless, I can't recommend this game right now unless that person is really into.. school management.
Final score:
3.3/10.0

54044311.review: This game is doing pretty well for early access. I've been kept busy for the last week trying to make the perfect school, and this is actually challenging enough that I haven't done it yet. In other sim games, there's commonly a "profit hurdle" which ends up being the main challenge of the game, but this game is complex enough that I haven't encountered that. I estimate that while this is in early access, this will keep the average person busy for 10-20 hours, many more once the devs add what they are planning to. The management part isn't perfect by far, but it allows for some pretty heavy micromanaging. The main issues I have with this game is that it seems impossible to feed all your kids, and that I have to hire way too many janitors to make my school clean. Currently working with about a 300 student school and I have close to 30 janitors. However, this may just be me not being efficient enough with the routing mechanic? Regardless, this game is good for people who like sim/management games. It might be worth it to wait for a sale (I bought this at $15), but it is still worth full price.

54023369.review:
Acadamia: School Simulator is a lovely strategy simulation game to play whenever you have some free time. It is similar, in a way, to Prison Architect (both in look and design) but the whole point in it is to build a excelling school, teach students so well that they have impeccable grades and ensure that students aren't all going outside to defecate in bushes because you forgot to build a toilet ... oops.
I thoroughly enjoy the game and would recommend it to anyone who likes management sims. It is filled with little touches which add more flair to the game. This includes things like the students giving love letters to each other or students thinking about cheeseburgers rather than focusing on what the teacher is telling them. 

If I was to give one criticism it would be that once I have researched everything on the game, and have completed all of the quests, I don't have much left to do. When playing most management sims usually they don't come to an end, or usually it is very difficult to reach the end. For example in Cities Skylines you almost never reach an end and almost constantly have something to do after weeks of gameplay. I know I can continue to expand and improve the school, and earn more money, but this seems tedious and less of a challenge once everything else is complete. It might be worth adding more quests and more things to research as this will keep the game interesting for a longer period of time.

Overall though I really enjoy the game and have been loving the improvements and content updates that the devs have been adding to it.

I wanted to love this game (it's been on my wishlist for ages)   But for the price, it just needs to be more substantial. I reviewed this game a while ago, and at the time gave it a mild NO recommendation. The developer politely asked that I keep an eye on the development to see if it gets better. I did, and I can honestly say this game got a lot better through the variations. It is still a pretty simplistic CMS - 2D with basic needs that need to be met while building up your school in size, prestige, and finances. But this game improved in 2 big ways that tipped the scales for me: 

1. before it felt a lot like there was just one way to get anything done, now there feels like there is a lot of versatility in the mechanics. I can have big or small classes, hire amazing teachers or lodes of okay ones. Whatever fits my stile for the mission.

2. the overarching goal of having your school go up in rank gives the game a bit more replayabilty (spelling?).  I don't know when this feature was added, pretty early on if I remember well. But it just makes me want to stick out with the game a little longer.

In short, I added an extra 60+ hours on the game. Worth it.

51297033.review:
It's a pretty fun game and a nice Prison Architect clone, but it's still a little lacking in content compared to it. After a couple of play sessions you'll already have built and done everything and there's not much else to do other than upgrade to better teachers. There aren't many challenges either, so you'll be done most of those in the first couple of school years and then you'll have to wait several more before you can complete any.

I'd love to see an option to buy the land around the school to keep expanding it, and maybe add electrical and plumbing to give the player a little more to manage. It could also use more items that students would find fun since keeping them happy is always an uphill battle.

It's definitely still worth playing in its current state, I'd just love to see them add a lot more to make it a more complete game.
