51065172.review:
Very impressive for an alpha game, in my opinion. There are certainly still some lingering problems (as expected) but I have got more time into this game than others I paid much more for, so it's hard to complain too much. Excited to see this develop further.

Pros:
--Overall a fun experience. It's sand-boxy enough to give some freedom but the grant system and research tree keeps you somewhat focused and moving forward, and it feels nice to progress the school

--Decent amount of depth, I still have a ways to go in getting a high grade for my school and building everything

--Works very well for an alpha game, I have only encountered one bug (described below)

Cons
--One major bug is that it seems basically impossible right now to feed students properly. No matter what you build cafeteria wise, they will always complain about a lack of food and some will even drop out because of it. I posted about the issue on the steam forums and the developer said they are working on it, so that's encouraging but it is quite frustrating at the moment

--Students/staff don't have much personality. Even though it's mostly just flavor text I would like to see some backstories/bios instead of just names and basic needs.

--I think random events and scenarios would go a long way to spice up the game in general.


Overall, I think this is a solid sim and a good buy, and has quite a bit of potential if the devs stick with it.

51053940.review:
A long time ago while this game was still in early access I released a review of this game, I'll admit I may have been a bit harsh when I compared this early access game to PA so I will offer my apologies on that if you will accept it, but after seeing some of the new mechanics I am thoroughly astounded with this games progression and improvement so I think it's time I update my review. My favourite mechanic is the energy selling, I just thought it was so unique compared to anything else I had seen. -Some of the new starter settings I thought gave the game especially sandbox mode more customisation(the flag customisation is a nice touch). 
-1 thing I noticed whilst hiring teachers was the "mellow," "strict," "boring," etc, modifiers, this is great, again something that gives the game a personal touch as anyone who goes to school knows which teachers they like and dislike and it's something so minor that you wouldn't even except but greatly improves the game. This also means that you can't just hire the teacher with the best qualifications, love it. 
-After checking the reaserch tree and finding the lawyer option to fire employees instantly, which is sort of funny, not really bad nor good but if it will extend the longevity of the game that is nice as that is one of the issues I had with PA as well, even if it's not the most useful the in the world if it's more things to add to your school it will help keep engagement as I always find selling my prison in PA is just not that satisfying after you've worked so hard to get to that point and it's like what now(ignore mods for my sanity plz). 
-Actually as for research, it's all an improvement, I would like to see the school programs expanded upon though as I find that is an interesting aspect of the game which could be nice to expand(referring to the recycling program) a final comment on it though, I'm mostly indifferent to the expand school population though there should be an option when the game is loaded in sandbox mode to set max population(within reason and if there is a reason why they can't do this then it's fine just a suggestion anyways) to allow for just messing around with the game or really big schools.

Overall my previous rating I would say was more like a 3/10
I would now put this at a 7/10.
This game still has steps to take before reaching the level of prison architect but I can confidently say that it's on it's path there.
Props to the dev team for improving this game and once again my apologies for my earlier review.

51049489.review:
[h1]An engrossing (if currently limited) school builder in the style of Prison Architect [/h1]

I love management games, so Academia really hit the spot! I've played Prison Architect, and it's cool to see how Academia managed to adapt those same mechanics for building a school.

The core mechanic is essentially constructing the different parts of a school, but you have to manage your students' needs, such as food or toilets. If you can't provide enough toilets, watch as your students end up peeing in the bushes, or even worse, leave your school altogether! Say goodbye to that tuition money.

One of the trickier things at the moment is definitely balancing money. The game's a little tougher from Prison Architect in the sense that you only get students at the beginning of the school year, instead of a new influx of people on the next day. And the little things that I need to keep [strike]precious tuition money[/strike] students from leaving slowly add up, and it's been a fun and careful balancing act managing all the costs. [i]Especially[/i] the toilets.

After playing 12 hours in, though, I'm definitely seeing the limits in the game. There aren't a lot of things to aim for anymore, besides getting #1 on the rankings or rebuilding the school all over, which I don't really have any incentive to do.

All in all, though, what they do have is great. It's fun to figure out in the first few hours, and here's hoping for more late-game developments. 

Here are some things I'd love to see:

- I know I have a rival, but why do I need to care about the rival? Why should I care about hitting the #1 rank? Would be cool to have some backstory or reasoning for the rival, just to make me work harder. Bonus would be if I could even check out my rival school, to really see what I'm up against. 

- I had the idea of building separate junior high and senior high buildings, until I realized that I have no idea if my faculty are going to be a mess going from one faculty room to the other. So, would be great if I could assign my faculty to specific faculty rooms once I build more of them.

- Clubs would be nice? Or random student-led initiatives. Having just graduated from college, I distinctly remember that a lot of things were driven by students instead of the admin, and it would make sense in the game for the students to have some more agency in shaping their school.   

- My 7 year-old cousin would like to request a school bus. And I wholeheartedly agree; it would be fun managing bus drivers and buses later into the game.

50626211.review:
[h1] Like Prison Architect Jr, except instead of all the cold-hearted sociopaths that game only had prisoners, ah high school.[/h1]


"Academia : School Simulator" is a blast for sure. There's something in particular about the animation style and the structure that suggests they drew a lot of inspiration from Prison Architect here. And, for those of you who aren't familiar with PA, well that commonality in design approach might as well be a written guarantee you're in for a good time here. There's hardly a better influence for the sort of simulator game Academia aims to be, and it's clear they paid attention to the lessons laid out before them by prior works in forging their own take on the genre.   

A lot of the design elements it took PA years in early access to sort out--like zoning and pathfinding for staff--Academia included right out the gate in the early access period. Now it's moving along its own journey of discovery towards their ultimate game vision.  Some of the more technical aspects you would find in PA and other sims aren't implemented here though. However, I'm not sure if those mechanics are "not yet added" or if it’s an intentional design choice in omitting things like electrical wiring and water pipes from the gameplay. Personally, I'm happy enough with it being omitted to focus on the core student experience since that level of micro-installation was always more a burden to me. Plus, there’s not really much strategy to be found in pipe placement here unless Little Timmy is going to be burrowing his way-out Shawshank style.... though if they do go the utility route, that’s something I'd definitely love to see, hah.  


I’ve also attached a video here covering the gradual end of my first play attempt, in which I go from a reasonable tight-position to totally F'd by the end. What's great is that despite failure, it's not s something found frustrating. Going into that final death-kneel I already knew what I screwed up earlier, and thus could actually learn from my mistakes for next time.  For games like simulators where it takes a long while to really get into those juicy parts that learning experience is especially a boon since you can otherwise burn out easily trying to jump into the next game without really knowing what to change for better results.  Something wonderful atop of all that, even when I hit that failure point, I kept playing anyway since it was actually really fun trying to dig my way out of that hole by gutting staff and carefully selected grant money goals. If even I collapsed in it. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wkTBrniBLD4

There's a whole lot I know to do going in to another gameplay, but it’s safe to say my main fuck up was…. Just not paying attention with a clicking selection like a major dumbass. I ended up hiring like 5 janitors in a row, that cost me thousands for upfront pay even while fired directly after, so I totally gimped myself early on.  The second part that killed me---and something that I'm not quite so sure as sure was my part---was that I was still being charged daily payments for a teacher I already fired on top of the cost of their cheaper replacement, so instead of being the cold-hearted move that saved my ass, it just buried me further with no way of getting out of that hole. I actually plan to hit the devs up about that though part since I'm thinking that was a bug  The latter part of my video ends up being pretty shitty since I was waiting out the clock thinking that at the end of the day their salary would stop being paid,  and then the next day before realizing it wasn't happening and I cost myself an extra $400 a day plus the 4g upfront for that new teacher instead of saving $500 by ditching a teacher costing me $900 daily. 

Oh!  And the bonus modes! I know this is MAJORLY important to select portions of the audience for these games who don't care about challenge, and just want to build their perfect vision. Yes, there absolutely is a free-range mode that just lets you do as you please. And if that weren't enough, there's already workshop support for mods to bend the game over backwards along with the usual texture replacement files and personal details at your leisure.  For those of you who do want general pressure curve but perhaps a lighter one, the starting map generation also gives the usual options for wiggle room with regard to base income and other settings too.

44702843.review:
While it still needs some polishing, the game is definitely quite a bit better than it was before when I last reviewed it.  The workers are considerably more responsive and though I feel they could still decide what their next task is more quickly, their performance at least means building even the basics of the school won't take a week in-game.
I also appreciate that a research tree has been added and the player effectively unlocks things on a gradual basis.  It allows the player to learn things and just take things a step at a time.  Avoiding an information overload.  It may slow things down a bit, but this is not a sort of game where you should be able to build absolutely everything in no time.
I've still yet to play this game more so I can't speak for how well the game maintains interest as you develop the school.  But the game feels good and playable now at least.

If you ever try it again and feel like it merits changing your review, we'd really appreciate it.  Thanks!

44700147.review:
I am a huge fan of Rimworld, I really enjoyed Prison Architect and plus, I'm a teacher.  So I was pretty excited about this game.

I'm giving it a hesitant thumbs up on the premise that it will deliver on its promises as it progresses through EA.  It's very bare bones at the moment but I'm hopeful that it will live up to its potential as its exactly the kind of game that I would love if it were much, much bigger.

As a teacher, I do have some feedback on the academic side of things for the developers:

-  Unique teacher profiles are great but perhaps star ratings should be given per experience rather than degree level.  Great teachers don't need a PhD, especially not for PE!  Also, why are they maxed out on only one subject area?  Some teachers are very well-rounded and schools often use them as substitutes for other subjects, or they compete with each other to teach in or lead different departments.  There are loads of interesting dynamics to explore here to add a different dimension to the game.

-  Can't the school and students have some choice over what subjects they provide/study?  More player-control over the schedule would be great.

-  Ugh, those chairs with attached tables.  I have never seen those in a real school, just old photos of instutionalised pupils with dead eyes from the horrors of rote learning and the cane.  And what's with the 19th century green chalkboards?  Can we have some modern day school furniture please?  I am unable to design a school that I would ever want to work in.  Aren't we living in the times of project-based learning and blended education?  Let's get some round movable furniture with wifi connectivity, gadgets for team tasks and graphics of students giving digital presentations.

-  Could we have a choice of principle at the start which will affect gameplay, like the storyteller in RimWorld or the prison manager in PA?  Also more variety of conditions at start up and some scenario options to improve replayability and offer increasing difficulty.

- At present I can't see how to keep my school progressing up the school rankings, but I am guessing this is because prestige and quality standards are still in development?  I have designed a clean, safe, profitable school with small class sizes quite easily but my ranking is still between 400-500.  I can't see what's going on here and the reports aren't particularly helpful or informative.

-  On this note, there should be bi-annual school inspections which threaten the school's access to grants or even threaten them with closure but offer higher prestige and affect how easily the school attracts new students.

- Getting new students is as easy as ordering them from a transfer button for next day delivery like some kind of child-trafficking branch of Amazon.  Instead parents should visit on open days at the beginning of the year (after build phase) and decide whether or not to enroll their child.  This would force you to manage your budget much better or accept less desirable students to be transferred if you get desperate.

-  As your prestige improves, the type of student you attract should better, but pressure to keep parents and inspectors happy should increase.


Overall, great start but you're still a way off your final draft.  C-

EDIT:  Since I wrote this review the developers have made some huge improvements.  I'm upping my grade to a B+.  Dusting off my pencil case for the new school year...
44700147.developer_response:
Hi, just reposting my reply on the discussion board here for the benefit of other players:

Hey Vilanelle, thanks so much for the great feedback. I would argue for a C+ over a C minus, but of course I would do that! To reply to some of your thoughts.

More player-control over the schedule :

To be honest this is probably not going happen any time soon. The reason being that the more control the player has over the schedule, the more havoc it will wreak on the AI. We'll continue to try to think of ways that the player can tweak the schedule, but I'm afraid for now this current setup will stay for a while.

Will more subjects become available with more individualised classrooms:

This is part of the plan, yes.

science/art lessons actually in the lab/art room :

This should have started happening with the latest update.

Ugh, those chairs with attached tables. I have never seen those in a real school, just old photos of instutionalised pupils with dead eyes from the horrors of rote learning and the cane. And what's with the 19th century green chalkboards:

Haha! I think our experience with school was a little different! I still remember those chalkboards in high school, and in the Philippines at least those seats are pretty standard. We opted for a more 90s style setup/decor because that's what we're more familiar with. I don't know that we'd be changing the facilities, something we're exploring is the ability to upgrade objects in the future.


Could we have a choice of principle at the start which will affect gameplay, like the storyteller in RimWorld or the prison manager in PA? Also more variety of conditions at start up and some scenario options to improve replayability and offer increasing difficulty:

Yes this will definitely happen. We'll be adding some more difficulty settings to the custom school screen hopefully in the next update (no promises, fingers crossed, etc. etc.). A choice of principal will added in the more distant future.

At present I can't see how to keep my school progressing up the school rankings:

This could be a matter of game balancing. We'll definitely be discussing this.

school inspections:

Definitely in the works. We're just figuring out the best way to integrate this into the game properly.

As your prestige improves, the type of student you attract should better, but pressure to keep parents and inspectors happy should increase:

This is one of our major mechanics that we hope we can add by the end of the year or early next year.

Unique teacher profiles:

We made the choice to use the degrees as an abstracted way of showing ranking, fully realizing that this isn't true to to life. I suppose we could have gone with a star rating, but as it is it's too deeply integrated into the game now for us to easily switch. We definitely want more variation within teachers, and once again that's something we're planning for in the future.

Thanks again for the great feedback, we hope you can give us another grade at the end of the year!

So far so good - Comparing this to Prison Architect, I have to say Academia's tool set is on par.  But!  There's a ruler tool included in the Blueprint (planning) suite.  Sometimes all you need are the little things in order to make something great.  Planning, building and management is strikingly similar to Prison Architech, so familiar players shouldn't have too much of a hard time learning the ins and outs of Academia.  Although the staff hiring reminds me a lot of Theme Hospital trawling threw prospective teacher's credentials - Getting a school off the ground is going to be somewhat tricky, but challenge accepted!  Just means, players like myself will be spending time in Sandbox Mode learning the game's intricacies through trial and error until we get a solid gameplan that works.  Currently running on my 2015 MacBook Pro and I am happy to report thusfar the game is nice and stable.

Like Prison Architect, Subnautica and so many other Early Access projects that blossomed into something truly awesome, Academia: School Simulator is yet another promising project that is worth getting behind!

43864588.review:
Before you buy this and play, it's important for you to remember that this game is in early access. The developers seem to be hard at work and very responsive.

I want to say right off the bat that I've not had any of the technical issues other people seem to have (crashing, freezing, slowing down). I'm playing on an ASUS ROG laptop that I purchased in 2013 and it's been running just fine for me.

I'm a teacher and thought this game would be fun to try. I think this shows great potential and I really enjoyed experimenting with what's there so far. While it's relatively easy to complete everything the game has to offer at the moment, it's still worth playing around with. I have a few suggestions for the developers of things that might be neat to add in the future. I'm not certain what it is they're working on and what they see for the full release of the game, but these could be things to explore:

- clubs
- social cliques (goths, jocks, nerds, thespians, etc)
- school competitions, assemblies, plays, etc ... even just an auditorium
- weather and/or seasons
- different classrooms for special area subjects such as P.E., art, and music
- other classes, like woodshop, home ec, computers, chorus, etc
- a wider selection of floors and decor
- customization for furniture (color, material, etc)
- some system for comfort - kind of like in The Sims where you need a certain amount of decor and windows. While the options for decor and windows are there in-game, it doesn't seem like a necessity aside from getting a small grant and some prestige
- a campaign mode would be really cool - you're given a school that has some sort of problem either with truancy or academics or something and you need to solve it
- more athletic options - swimming pool, wrestling room, weight room, track, basketball court, soccer field, football field, etc
- staff and faculty seem really go-with-the-flow ... what if there were internal conflicts or someone suddenly decides to quit? Or maybe staff or faculty demands better working conditions or smaller class sizes or they'll go on strike or quit?
- if your school starts becoming rowdy, it might be interesting to have students form gangs that you need to deal with
- branching off rowdier schools, vandalism is something else to explore
- enacting certain school codes, like dress codes, or even just situations like running in the hall, no smoking, food fights might be hilarious and fun to break up, students fighting in general, students arriving to school late
- I would absolutely love to play the game as a primary school, too ... I teach kindergarten and I wish there was a simulator that went K-3 or even 3-6. Most decent school simulators are high school

I'm sure I'll come up with more, but that was the list I made so far.

I'll definitely stick around and keep an eye on what the devs do with this game!

43054905.review:
August 28th 2020 update:
This game is very much playable, and I would recommend it for general simulation that vaguely resembles a school management.  However, I personally do not find that it has enough personality to give it a thumbs up at this time.  Most of the points I raised below still stands though with some improvements on teacher hiring, student behaviors (including added speech bubbles), and prestige effect for admission.  It's definitely sad to me that I can build a school that is much more profitable as a utilities company selling water, electricity, and trash due to absolutely no true alternative revenue streams (or even a way to even tweak my tuition) that in any way relates to academia.  As I said before, I truly like the concept but it has a ways to go before I can recommend it.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Original Review

I have been waiting for a school simulator for a while.  After playing for a few hours, I can honestly say that this game (in the early access stage) isn't it.  I truly wish that there is a button for "Wait" instead of just Yes/No.  Alas, I digress.  I’ll update the review once they’ve had more time to release more content.
First, I must point out that, as far as early access games go, this one has a lot of potential, and is more polished than most at this stage. It isn't loaded with high end graphics, so not much can go wrong there.  It also has games like Prison Architect and Rimworld that came before to set the standards for what we would expect in a management game of this style.  I will also say, with full disclaimer, that I have played both of those titles thoroughly and enjoy them massively, but it just doesn't quite scratch the itch of a non-murderous-prisoners/aliens/slaves/nomads/pirates/you-name-it simulation.  I was looking forward to some frivolous high-school drama, and an easy-going simulation to pleasantly pass an hour or two where I can build my nice academic empire, and maybe pull a senior prank or two.  It isn't quite there yet.
What it does have going for it:
1. Standard learning curve
2. Customization of school seal and motto
3. School-themed
4. A really responsive dev team

What it lacks:
1. There is an awesome feature where you can tweak your class schedule, but only by moving a recess and a lunch slot.  You are forced to have 6 class periods, 1-hour recess, and 1-hour lunch.  Also, the schedule is locked for each grade year (e.g.  if you want to set the lunch break to 12, you must do it for ALL seniors, instead of for specific class).  The classes are also set: no electives.  Or rather, students do electives during their recess periods, which involves library, art, computer lab, or just hanging out.  
2. The game-play is structured more like an elementary school than a high school, where teachers come to you, not the other way around.  What this translate to, then, is you have one classroom for each grade year, then you just have 6 teachers go around to teach those 6 classes.  There is no penalty to the class sizes, BUT, there is a penalty to the number of teachers.
3. Teachers... You can hire teachers by their education level.  Bachelor's level teachers are dumb as a brick, and PhD teachers are brilliant.  PhD teachers cost a fortune to maintain but are highly efficient.  Now, I am not a teacher, but I can tell you that this is already flawed.  There were college courses that I took in my younger years that I wished were taught by some of my high school teachers who had bachelor's degrees.  This is not a college simulator, having only PhD teachers be the only worthwhile option just doesn't make any sense (can someone point out why you would ever keep non-PhD teachers in this game?).  
4. Lack of class variety.  Since the teachers come to the student, not the other way around, all classes are plain.  It discourages you from spending the time to design a nice science lab.  Gym? No gym.  Just another boring classroom with a P.E. teacher at the chalkboard.  Really?  I’m sorry theater fan, I’m not even going to mention you.
5. Money?  Income is solely through subsidies.  This doesn’t make sense to me.  Schools don’t pay vendors to bring in vending machines; vendors pay schools to bring them in.  I’m also pretty sure I had to pay for school lunches (Yes, I understand there are subsidies for low income households, allowances for unpaid lunch accounts, etc.), but this game, no charging lunch.  Instead, you must hire cooks and pay for the ingredients to feed your entire student body AND staff.  Really?
6. Transfer students.  You adjust a little slider, and you get the specified number of students (in the specified grade level) in a day or two.  This is just plain lazy, in my opinion, especially when the game already tracks prestige.
7. All those <sarcasm>great</sarcasm> school events that anyone might remember from their childhood?  Non-existent.  No science fairs with the volcanoes.  No awkward proms/formals.  No random school pride days and pep rallies.  Graduation?  No such thing.  Field trips? Forget it!  What do you have? Exam day, that happens overnight after Day 9 each year.  At least there is still that planned varsity sports thing we can look forward to?

Here are some things I think are missing:
1. Private vs Public school mechanics.  
•	In the public-school scenario, you get a yearly budget to educate an X number of student.  The budget may increase/decrease each year by scripted external events (e.g. city provided XYZ company with massive subsidy caused school budget shortfall), but the number of student just keeps growing.
•	In the Private school scenario, students pay tuition.  You get student based on your prestige.  Good teacher-student ratio adds prestige.  State of the art facility adds prestige.   High matriculation and college enrollment adds prestige.  More prestige = more student and ability to charge higher tuition.  Lower prestige = less tuition (if you want anyone to come to your school).  
2. True economy.
•	Add bistro area, in addition to plain cafeterias with outside vendors
•	Add student jobs, especially since some vocational program paid students (e.g. the cooking class pays the student servers for the student run dining option, the school bank pays their workers, the auto-shop pays their students for side jobs, etc)
•	Add ability to earn side revenue from food/events/ticket sales that can then be used to reinvest in bigger and better facility, events, vendors, food options, etc
3. Student housing for boarding school/hybrid.  There is so much possibilities down this venue, I’m not even going to list.
4. As previously mentioned, add some of the school events that are prime-drama producer.  Make it an event, add some modifiers to those boring students like science fair winner, varsity cheer leader, class president, D&D club, etc.  Make me care about those little figures running about.  I’d like to see a graduation ceremony where a little kid that frequented the principal office Freshman year gets recognized as most improved. 
5. What about drama?  There are the bullies, the truants, and the rowdy.  But, I don’t see food fights, or students being chased outside the school, or kids running around the hallway screaming.  I mean, put in a word bubble or something to denote them shouting in class or horse playing.
6. Reward having more fun and unique classes.  Don’t reward users for building 4 massive classes with hundreds of seats, with the standard mandatory 6 teachers.  It defeats the purpose of having departments.

I know this is probably harsh for an early access game, but I have to wonder out loud: What is the value being added to this game that a mod for Prison Architect or Rimworld can’t presently accomplish?

41597108.review:
At it’s core this game is a ‘build things to get you money to build more things’ type of a game and for the most part the core mechanics of the game are enjoyable in and of themselves. Your workers are a little dim so really you can only build one thing at a time which makes for a fun challenge. However there are features of the game that I feel should and could add challenge and complexity that just don’t at the moment. 

For example, getting a positive cashflow is really just a matter of making as large a classroom as possible and fitting as many chairs in it as you can. Whilst there is a student hunger, bladder and motivational score it’s not really clear what drives these or more importantly how they effect the amount of money you have/ ability to build the next thing. For example , I made the worlds best cafeteria, easily accessible etc but a bunch of the students were still starving and yet I still had plenty of money and students were still coming to school. Without any effect of poor health etc you just don’t really care and 50% of what should be the games core mechanic becomes obsolete.

It takes about 4-5 hours to complete all of the objectives the game offers and there’s no real incentive to do it outside sandbox mode. Once you achieve all the objectives the fun kind of runs out the gate.

Outside the objectives to build new things there are no objectives that actually involve you managing anything efficiently (like student health etc) and there are no missions or campaign mode like ‘fix this broken school’. I feel like the game has a great centre to it but there a bunch of tools that are really cool but are never utilized.

I know this review sounded mostly negative but there is still a solid 7-8 hours of fun to be had so I would still recommend it. Designing your school and watching it grow was fun.

40947894.review:
Academia: School Simulator, currently in Early Access, is a cute little game based around the creation of your very own high school. You start from the ground up, selecting grants with certain qualifications to earn money for the building of classrooms and other school-oriented buildings, hiring staff, placing furniture, and selecting decorations. One could chose to spend all of their grant money making a beautiful school that parents dream of sending their kids to, or a player could spend as little as possible cramming tons of desk into tiny classrooms with the intent of hoarding money. 

I am fond of the progression of the grants; done in order these teach you the fundamentals of the game without feeling like a lengthy tutorial. Once completed, though, the only goal of the game seems to be to grow the school’s population bigger and bigger, making it easy for interest in the game to fade. Being in Early Access, though, I have high hopes that the amount to do in the game will grow, so this is hardly a fault. 

Money is certainly a challenge, but once you find the happy place of keeping your finances in the green, things get quite a bit easier. It is possible for the game to shut down your school if you run out of money, but starting up the most recent load seems to trick the game into allowing you to continue making the threat much lower.

This game also isn’t buggy at all for me, a huge plus for a game that is in Early Access as I am someone who has learned to expect some level of technical difficulty playing a game that is not fully released yet.

Overall, though there is not too much to really do in this game, I see a lot of potential here. It would be worth playing if you generally like these planning and management sims. Although I have already completed most of the grants and gotten my school’s population over 500, I will probably continue playing every once in a while, and will definitely pick it up again when more content is added.

40403866.review:
So I bought this because simulation games are my bag. Right now, as you'd expect from an early access game, Academia is very bare bones. It has the absolute basics of the gameplay one might expect from a school-sim, and not much else besides.

Features are very sparse, gameplay is honestly rather same-y and tedious, and there's as much variation as a straight line. This makes for rather boring gameplay, and really it's not worth playing past the first school year. The graphics are simplistic and clean, the soundtrack is a little unforgettable, and the interface can be a little obtuse. Ambient sound effects, such as students chattering, construction work, or clatter in the school kitchens, are nearly nonexistant save for the school bell. Furthermore, there are indeed a number of bugs, mostly graphical glitches so far.

So why am I recommending this? Simply put, what IS there seems promising, and there's room to expand. As we're in such an early stage, one would expect the game to be fairly basic until new features are added in. And it seems as though Squeaky Wheel does indeed intend to add more, if hints on the interface are to be believed. Consider this less "Buy this game now!" -- the game is nowhere near worth £15 right now -- and more a "Watch this closely" kind of deal.

39941391.review:
When I found out about this game navigating through steam, I had to get it. It is just a pity it is still in its early stages, so we all have to wait until its full release. It has a lot of pontential. What we have so far is the core of the game done well indeed - no game killing bugs, great arts and it runs smoothly. In fact, if there are any bugs, at the end of the game's day, the system restarts and all the apparent bugs go away as the next school day begins. 
 For gamers like me who love and play management games, the challenges so far are not hard at all. Starting with plenty of money, I never go below 70% of my funds ever. Perhaps, harder levels should be added for those who prefer dealing with difficult financial troubles (think about less startup money and a huge bank loan at hefty interest rates). Government funds for a private school such as this should also not come easy. 
The infinite budget sandbox mode should not be in the main menu at all, but within a submenu, preferably saying - "n00bs sandbox" or something akin to DOOM easiest mode.
As far as buiding a school goes, in terms of doing whatever you want, I think a classroom should not necessarily have 10 student's tables, but none at all. Kids should just sit on the floors, why not? I like the fact, classrooms can be outdoors, so sitting on the grass and no 10 tables required should be the way to go.
Looking forward to:
- vertical buildings;
- school activities;
- music classrooms, gyms, pool (outdoors type as well),
- natural elements (raining, snowing, scorcihng sun - all able to be turned on and off by the players)
- annoying parents telling the principal what to do
- unruly staff (they all work so perfectly, humm, like machines - wages setting)
- teacher's age (teachers working year after year can become later vice-principals....in your second branch somewhere else) Yes we should own more than one school and having someone realiable working there.
- kids' love for the school - they can go away if they feel the school is not their second home
- gardens and trees in need of tending (hiring gardeners)
- choosing or not school uniforms
- adding CCTV cameras in each room
- middle and primary school and kindergarten (college and university)
- lots of drama (drugs, romance, pregnancy, illnesses, death, parent's death)
-  after-school programs
- night-time classes for adults (like cooking, sewing, foreign language, mechanic classes)
- Vending machines generating income to the school
- Car or Bus Drop-Off zones 
- character traits and vices for students (Like genius or great leadership/ lazy and depressed)
- time outs; suspension, after-class detention 
- students making their own friends, rather than just going to school and learning
- (school shooting is not cool and totally passable - we want to have fun after all thinking about managing a school not having to deal with this craziness).

39920392.review:
I wanted to like this game, I really did. I thought that a prison architect style game with a school theme would be a lot of fun but...

All it did was make me want to play prison architect.

This game is just a worse version of PA. The construction feels clunky, The school feels lifeless, and it doesn't seem like the ammount of students you want to transfer matters as all available seats just fill up when you start the school year. My love of PA did kind of taint my experience, but that's to be expected if you are going to make a clone. I feel like this game would be far better as a mod for PA. The UI made me realize how well PA did their UI. Having to create routes for monitors and janitors just felt like a chore. Like I said, all this game did to me was make me want to go play PA. 

If you don't own Prison Architect and think you may want to play this game then just buy Prison Architect instead.
If you do own Prison Architect, just go play that instead. 

In it's current form, this game just isn't worth the TWENTY DOLLARS that they're asking for. It's totally classless to think that this game is worth only ten dollars less than it's far superior father. 

Final Verdict: Very disappointing.

39325101.review:
I played with this a little bit, and I'm intrigued, but not impressed. I've put a lot of hours into similar games like Prison Architect, and I got this because I wanted to build something new. 

First off, the graphics and UI are OK. They could be better, but they work. The music is repetitive and frankly I could do without it. There are a few bugs, like when installing a window the workmen climb through the new opening to leave instead of using the door like a normal person. The other one I've seen is where the workmen lay a floor different than what you ordered.

I'd like to know where the developers went to school, because it resembles no high school I've ever been to:
1. Students should arrive and depart mostly by school bus or car.
2. In real high school there is no recess. The commons area is usually the same as the cafeteria. Instead, there are clubs, usually before or after school. This could be made to really affect the student's behavioral and academic experience.
3. Several rooms appropriate to a high school are missing: 1) gymnasium, 2)wood shop, 3) metal shop, 4) drafting, 5) cooking, 6) sewing, 7) science lab, 8) stage or auditorium, 9) msuic, band, or choir. Basically, half the school is still missing.
4. I've yet to see students change classes for different periods, nor have I seen lockers or the need for them. 
5. Even though it's your school you can't schedule classes or change the bell schedule. As the principal, you should have the option to get overly creative with the bell schedule. Schedule different lunches to optimize cafeteria space, schedule study periods, allow more or less time to pass from class to class, etc.
6. While not a hard and fast rule, typically I see the principal handling the teachers and budget, while there is a vice principal who usually takes care of discipline problems. When I was in high school the vice primcipal was the man we feared.
7. Almost every school I've ever seen has a detention room. Students should have a deterrent from being rowdy, and ideally, they should have a reward for achievement (dances, field trips, play days, pizza party, awards ceremony, anything)
8. The school's crest and motto should mean something. For example, some things about the school could be easier or more challenging depending on which four symbols are in your crest. Like the basketball could give a bonus to athletics and P.E., while the atom could boost science education.

This game more closely resembles an elementary school. Add a playground for recess and change from "freshman, sophomore, junior, senior" to "first grade, second grade, third grade, fourth grade" and you've pretty much got it. Somebody should make that mod already.

So, to the developers: I realize your programmers, but have some kids and go to a school and see what's really in there, then make the game.

I don't think I'll return it because I think it has potential and I'm hoping it will improve greatly, but I would recommend waiting to buy it until it's at a further stage of development. It's definately no Prison Architect, at least not yet. As it is, it's probably worth about half the price it's offered at.

39283717.review:
I don't think this is a bad game. I just noticed that the game devs actually read these so I was wondering to make some tips what I think the game needs to level up.

Overall, if you like building games, this is for you.

After 2,5 hours of purely sandboxing I got these thoughts:
- The options menu doesn't show the quick-buttons for example for rotating objects, nor let's you change them. ( I just figured everything out by just pushing everything ) So maybe adding a changing option helps the ones that doesn't like playing hide and seek.
- Some of the builders prioritize the objects, even there would be walls, floor or doors still in development, getting themselves trapped. Maybe you could change them to at least go by walls -> doors -> floor -> objects? Or maybe put two kinds of builders?
- The system that you have to make a trash can, hit demolish and wait for it to get demolished is way too slow. It would be nicer if you could just throw it to time and space, so if you'd like to build something immediately you don't have to wait someone to get it away first. Or maybe something else? It just feels a bit dumb, even I kind of recognize what you have tried to do here.
- I would like to have a feature that the school atmosphere could be raised with plants, posters, swings etc. and maybe bullying, unclean places and such could decrease it or sth. The fact was that I wanted some plants but there was none, please let me have plants!
- It feels kind of stupid that the builders don't have anything in their space. Why not add those containers where they could sleep and rest during the day?
- I would also appreciate to get info of how many food boxes you need per human and how many food grannies to make them a meal. I had a lot of food not in my freezers but everyone still get their food and no one complained?
- The transfer student system is a bit unclear - do I have to make them space to the classes or is there going abroad as many students of mine?
- Maybe in somewhere in the future we could get more floors to the schools?

Sorry about a longish post, I really like this game and I'm looking forward to see where it goes!

I always love sandbox games because it gives me the ability to play God. It's up to me to create the world; it's up to me how I manage a society/group/team; it's up to me how I mold the people's personality. I always love the idea of making my own high school and Academia: School Simulator provides you that kind of simulation.

After playing the game for a few hours, it seems that I have already seen what it the early access has to offer, but I can say that is has a lot of potential to become something more. They already did a good job with the building system and the objects.

In my opinion though, they could add a little more content to the game such as adding a story mode to it, and maybe some flesh-out characters. More objects to decorate the school and for the students/staff to use. Events such as festivals or holidays or examinations. Different kinds of interactions or actions such as giving love letters, or throwing paper planes at your classmate heads. 38550539.review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review

PLEASE NOTE (2017): Due to recent false accusations of plagarism, I (the reviewer) would like to stress that all these reviews and upcoming reviews are original and are not blatantly copied. Other reviews are used to help stress my point across but are changed in such a way to make the review in my own wording [/h1]

Academia: School Simulator is a game developed and published by Squeaky Wheel Studio Inc.

I have been patiently waiting for a game where you can run your own school, after playing School Tycoon to death back in the day, sadly that game is no longer available to play both physically and digitally, so I had to patiently wait for another studio to come up with a school simulator where you can be the head of a school and run the school of your dreams

So, is Academia: School Simulator worth it? Well...

Currently, with this review being written whilst it's in early access, it is definitely an odd one. I recommend this game to support it within it's current state, but honestly... it's just not worth playing, not yet anyway...

The foundation of a school simulator and that of a fun game really is there, as are most of the basic rooms and functionalities, but it's also about as early access as you can get...

You set up a school, simple. Build classrooms, bathrooms, a cafeteria, a faculty, an office, home room and that's basically it... so long as your students are healthy and happy, they go from year to year with a minimum of fuss. Sure, there are a few strange bugs and the AI gets a bit annoying in certain parts, but it's never really enough to get in your way or is game breaking

There's no fights, although there is bullying, but at the time this review was written, it's incredibly basic. There's no drama with students, no dropouts, no sport functions or buildings, no prestige, no head-start, no parents, no politics, no cheating, no strikes, and everything else you would normally see in a school. Honestly, play it for roughly two or three hours max and you've seen everything the game has to offer

It's incredibly bare bones but there is a lot of potential here, and I want to see this become as good as Prison Architect and I want this to be the next School Tycoon game, but as it is right now, think twice before purchasing it. If you want to support the developers, pay the full price but if you want to actually play it and have fun and explore what the game wants to offer to you, then wait for it either to add a few more updates first or when it completely leaves early access

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

36577798.review:
To all fans of "Prison Architect" who liked that game to the extent of wanting something akin, with similiar mechanics, basic game concepts and aesthetics but with something else than a prison to run (a highschool  in this case) - this is definitely a title you don't want to pass by.
At the time of this post, a title in early access, yes, but as other folks have pointed out by now this game has the makings of a great sim. The way I see it the tracks are set, and the developers seem quite eager to mold Academia into the game they invisioned, taking in account the recommendations of those who have experienced its alpha.

That being said, the game is still quite early in its development, and it shows: once you have reached "late game" (which for me was the freshmen's transition to sophomors) there is little to experience outside of grinding, expanding and taking in more transferees.
At this point I personally have the gall to propose to the developers to, for now, not bother with "fluff" like student/teacher character,bullies and additional zones and focus instead on making a balanced difficulty progression (things like challenges, crises and missions, as well as a more dynamic income/expenditure system).
But hey, that's just me.

All in all though, the potential is seeping with Academia, making it enjoyable enough in the early stages. 
So if you're into PA and controlling a school instead of a prison in similiar fashion sounds like a fun concept to you, definitely support the devs.

Again, makings of great sim.

36561345.review:
Would I recommend as an Early Access Game? Yes. Is this game anywhere near complete? No.

I have thoroughly enjoyed this game so far, and probably will continue to do so as more content is released, however after playing for about 2 hours today I feel I have done everything the game has to offer right now. 

If you enjoy prison architect, or games like theme hospital - you'll definitely enjoy this game. Try and build the biggest school you can! At this stage, however, there isn't much incentive to try and build a fairly big school as the last four or so 'quests' only involve having a certain number of students in the cohort.

Suggestions for later additions: 
- Senior Leadership, and other teaching staff: Schools have headteachers, leads for behaviour, SEND, and safeguarding all of which have a vital role to play in a school day. Also teaching assistants would be a valuable way to improve student attainment.
- Students out of class: punishment, detention!
- Parent-teacher conferences
- Gymnasium
- Sports field
- Outside playing area
- Students moving for different classes: rather than have each classroom a specific year group, why not have subject specific classrooms
- And finally a cosmetic change: all the menus for zoning/objects have everything in a completely different order. Can it be in some sort of order, or alphabetised?

On the whole, I believe this game has real potential - and you should definitely buy it!

36250519.review:
For the 2 hours I have played this game (in sandbox mode) I, overall, enjoyed the game even though it is very simple but there is so much potential. What we have to keep in mind is that it is still a very early access game.

The building aspect is very similar to that of Prison Architect, which I am a HUGE fan of, so if you have played that game or something similar to it then you know the controls already but there are a few differences which seem to be the same as SimAirport. 
There are not a lot of choices when it comes to wall and floor colours e.g. I really hate that there is only one type of wood and carpet flooring so I hope we get more colours to really make each room stand out. 
  
Playing is simple, maybe too simple at the moment as there really is no challenge or "End Goal". Your students and teachers go about their school day, learning, teaching, eating and leaving...thats it. It would be nice in future updates if we can create our own schedules for each year group and see different types of students like bullies, geeks, jocks, cheerleaders ect. to make the game a little more lively maybe even problems like a fire broke out in the kitchen or frogs ecsaped from the labs (if we ever get rooms like that).

There is so much that can be added to this game like...buying more land to expand on, doing PE instead of being stuck in the class room, making our own scheduels , clubs, school trips. I will leave my list there as there are many many things I would love to see added in future updates.

Does the price reflect the game? No. I think the £14.99 I paid for this game is too much for the little amount of gameplay I get. So my advice to others is that it might be an idea to wait for it to be on sale or more things have been added. If it was lower say...£8.99 - £10.00 then it would be about right for what you get ingame.
It would be nice to see the Developers push to get more updates out in a month or have one BIG update at the end of the month like some games I have played, unless it is a bad bug or crashes which they update as soon as they have fixes. 

Do I recommend this game? Yes mostly but a little no. Yes because I can see some really great protential in this game and as long as you understand that this is a very early access game and are happy with basic objects, game play and are also happy to wait for updates then go for it! No mainly because of the price, for me it is just a little to much for the little you get if it was lower then it would be yes all the way.

Overall score...6/10

This is an odd one.  I recommend this game to support it, but it's honestly not worth playing.  Not yet.

The foundation of a fun game really is there.  As are most of the basic rooms and functions.  But it's also about as early access as you can get.

You set up a school.  Classrooms, bathrooms, lunchroom, faculty, free time and that's basically it.
So long as your students are healthy and happy, they go from year to year with a minimum of fuss.  Sure there's a few strange bugs and the AI gets questionable, but it's never really enough to get in your way.

There's no fights, no drama, no dropouts, no sports, no prestige, no head-start, no parents, no politics, no cheating, no strikes, etc. etc. etc.  Play it for 2 hours and you've seen everything.

So why the thumbs up?  Because let's be honest, there's A LOT of potential here, and I want to see this become as good as (or even better than) Prison Architect, whose artist is also working on this.  If you want to support it, pay the 20 bucks.  If you want to actually play it and have fun, wait a year or two.

34989612.review:
I've literally been playing nonstop for the past 7 hours. Definitely takes me back to the good times in middle school when I was obsessed with School Tycoon. This game is highly addicting, especially if you like designing, managing things, and seeing your creation slowly grow. I also really like the animations and bgm. I've pretty much done all I could in this game as of now (wishing there was more to do, but it's still in Early Access so I understand). I'm very, very excited and have high hopes for the new updates. :)

Some ideas and features I'd like to suggest: 
- School events, fun and moral boosting scenarios/cutscenes after achieving certain goals (i.e: book fairs, dances, etc)
- A variety of clubs that could boost students' stats (i.e: art, music, chess, journalism, etc)
- More objects that are decorative but also useful (i.e: vending machines, phones, posters, wall fire extinguisher, newspaper dispensers, fences, etc)
- More types of faculty & their respective offices (i.e: the principal, counselors, librarian, security, maintenance etc) 
- A gym for P.E (swimming pools would be amazing tbh)
- Different food qualities (i.e: ability to train cooks)
- More zones (i.e: detention room, theatre room, reception, school newspaper, science lab, student council, etc)
- Different personalities for students that causes them to behave in a certain way (i.e: Delinquent, Teacher's Pet, Dreamer // vandalizing, sleeping in class, gossiping, picking up trash, joining student council)
- Adding the four seasons (i.e: Summer: student's complaining about heat (install AC/fans), Fall: leaves turn orange, decorations like pumpkins are added, Winter: snow, students building snowmans, Spring: allergy season)   
- Player's ability to catch rule violators (i.e: using their phones during class) by clicking on them and having an option to send them to detention, and boosting some sort of school rating haha) 
- More freedom of choosing whether certain zones could be indoors or outdoors
- Co-op?! That would seriously be so fun.

Would like to see fixed/changed:
- Ability to put trees on grass
- Option to edit the placement of an object (i.e: rotating it, changing the color, placing it somewhere else)
- Ahead-of-time warning before going bankrupt :(

34914257.review:
This game has a lot of potential, but as is, it's definitely in the very early stages of early access.  Since a lot of people have mentioned Prison Architect, I will agree it has a very similar vibe but is very, very simplified even from fairly early stages of Prison Architect's Alpha phases.  I don't think the game is so complex that a tutorial is in any way neccessary right now.  If you're familiar with other sim games, you'll figure out how to get started and going fairly easy, and like Prison Architect Alpha it has a to-do list as the basis of some guidance.  The only thing that was less than intuitive with the GUI was how to set boys and girls bathrooms.  If you go to edit zone for the most part the only option is to remove the zone rather than actually make any changes to it, but it also gives you the option to change the bathroom gender and grade level for classes.  Other than that, the game is pretty simple and intuitive for those familiar with the genre.

That said, I'm only recommending it if you're interested in supporting the developers.  If you're hoping for a game as enjoyable as mid to late stages of Prison Architect alpha testing, you're going to want to wait a while.  Currently, there is absolutely no problems to manage in the game.  You start with ample funds to have students in small class sizes with the best teachers no problems.  There is no conflict that arises aside from frequently sick students due to a dirty school, but I'm not 100% sure why that's happening aside from my janitors being slackers, and there are no consequences for it.

Long term, things that would likely improve the game are adding objectives/failure clauses such as ways to measure the student body as a whole's learning (though that might be a result of trauma from the American Education system, aha), more effort in attracting parents to transfer students to your school through meeting academic or musical/athletic goals with your students such as competitions you send specific students to and making more money possible only after reaching certain objectives.  The introduction of delinquents is a start on making the game more whole, but there's a long way to go to add depth.

Also, A+ for using the Prison Architect artist.  His/Her art is so cute <3

34851686.review:
Intro:
     So far so good! I absolutely love this game! If it keeps going well, this will be one of my top favorite of all time games. I subscribed to the subreddit, email, twitter and the youtube channel so I don’t miss a single thing. If you liked or loved Prison Architect, you will feel the same way or stronger about Academia. It takes on a very similar gameplay and artwork to that game. I messaged the Dev on Twitter and sure enough, the artist from PA is on this game and he is working in a small group to make Academia. This is his own project and he is passionate about it. I expect great things from this game and I bought 2 copies right when I could on launch day. 
Summary so far:
	You start out with a blank slate in an open canvas as you prepare to make your school. You have 3 zones already that you can of course change. You have deliveries, garbage, and an area for your workers. At this point, there are no scenarios or tutorials implemented yet but that should change over time. To get a sort of tutorial now, you can just take on a grant, finish the grant, then move to the next. In this way, you will get the idea and progress. I haven’t played until end game or anything yet but I can see how it will progress based on what I’ve done so far. The gameplay is similar enough to PA to know what to do intuitively but it is a different game still. You can hire at this point: janitors; teachers; workers; cooks and nurses. This game is based on a high school so there is freshman through senior classroom zones to make. There is even the ability to have a bathroom for men or women. This game looks, feels, and sounds great. It’s a very positive experience so far. I would definitely recommend this game to add to your collection. 

Pros:
•	Great art
•	Great music
•	Great UI experience
•	Intuitive menus for building and management tasks
•	Sandbox mode for just playing around or experimenting
•	Great communication with players and perspective players
•	A team that can be trusted in early access to deliver and not abandon the project
•	Tasks don’t take too long to get done by workers
•	Being able to vote on the next game project for the devs

Cons:
•	Some editing tasks can be tedious such as having to bulldoze grass if you lay down grass and want to change it to something else like concrete tiles
•	Not enough tile and wall pieces yet
•	Lack of campaign so far
•	Lack of proper tutorial so far
•	Slow loading to start the game

Verdict:
     I won’t give a game that released practically a second ago a numerical value or something of the like. I can say that the issues with the game so far will most likely be fixed over time. I don’t see my cons as permanent problems. I simply added them because they are there. If I were to recommend the game or not, I would always recommend it. This is a great start to what will become a great game. I say go for it! 

Still not sure:
	I can blame you if you don’t know if you should get it or not. I recommend checking out the dev logs and gameplay videos on Youtube. I would also check out the site. That should help you decide for sure. Some games in early access are simply not worth getting yet until they fix and add more content. I think this is one game worth getting and enjoying the journey over time.

34843974.review:
Academia: School Simulator, is a very fun idea and the simplistic but awesome art style that is similar to Prison Architect is awesome. It's extremely fun to play, as it's a "Prison Architect" meets high school, which is again a lot of fun.
However the game is EXTREMELY lacking in content, and even basic things like zones are too buggy right now.
Want an L shaped kitchen? Can't. Once you make a zone by clicking and dragging and letting go, that's the zone. Adding another zone to it won't make it one zone. You can build everything within 10 minutes, not even using sandbox mode.

Pro's:
- Loveable art style
- Groundwork is there
- Make a school emblem, motto and name.
- You can give classrooms names
- Big map, so you can build a huge campus

Cons:
- No dorms/beds. Students simply go home (not even using a school bus)
- Very limited amount of zone types and things to do
- In current state, absolutely not worth the pice.
- Can't rename students/teachers or staff.
- Can't buy land to make an even bigger school
- Everything can be built in 5-10 minutes, leaving you with nothing to look forward to.
- High graphical settings can bug out your game, huge amount of memory also used
- No missions/challenges or anything really to make it more interesting
- No tutorial, you are thrown in and you have to figure it out all by yourself

Final thoughts:
I will update this when updates come to add new zones/items etc ofcourse.
If you want to support the devs, and believe they won't abandon this project, then I'd say buy it.
If you want a prison architect game that is about schools, do not buy this yet.
Is it right now worth 16 euros? ABSOLUTELY NOT!

[h1]Academia: School Simulator[/h1]
[b]1.9 Hours On Record At Time Of Review[/b]

  First of all, I love builders.  Played prison architect for quite awhile, and found out that the same artist that made that game, did this as well. I was very pleased. So the usual caveat of “It’s an Early Access Game” applies here. You take that on board when you buy the game so early. You can definitely tell that it has roots from Prison Architect as it has that same charm, look and feel about it – just without the gritty nature. It’s fairly easy to pick up and play without instruction, even if it does seem a little daunting at first: But if you’ve played the likes of Prison Architect, Sim Airport, Another Brick In the Mall etc then you will be fine with this. I’ve clocked up an hour on the game and enjoyed that hour – There’s not much to do in the game at the moment, other than a few classes, cafeteria and support functions; which you’ll master all of that in no time at all - so an hour is pretty much all you need **RIGHT NOW** but that’s OK. It all runs as you expect it, was stable enough and never once did I think “Oh God, I’d rather play something else” before I felt like I was done.
Right now, it’s not an addictive game like Prison Architect, Another Brick or Sim Airport is.. but that’s purely due to the size of the game right now and not because of the quality of what has been released so far.
